Guiseley's Jake Cassidy and Kevan Hurst were substituted in the second half, while Gateshead's Gus Mafuta received a yellow card. The match was attended by a crowd of 1,123 people.

The passage discusses Bristol Sport Ltd's plan to increase the capacity of a football club by replacing two stands, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale. The plan has been approved by Bristol City Council and is pending a judicial review period. If no judicial review is initiated by March, the redevelopment will commence in May. The information was confirmed by majority shareholder Steve Lansdown at a shareholder meeting.

The passage discusses the suspension of shale gas drilling, also known as "fracking", by Cuadrilla in Lancashire, UK, following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is monitoring the situation, and Cuadrilla is examining the data before deciding to resume. The process of fracking involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas. The BGS has reported two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in March, and has stated that any process that injects pressurized water into rocks at depth can cause earthquakes. The BGS also mentioned that the latest tremor took place 1.2 miles (2km) away from the drilling site. The energy select committee has called on ministers to support the process in the UK, arguing that environmental problems associated with it in the US can be overcome by tight regulation and good industry practice.

63-year-old Angus Carpenter, a busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015, but was cleared of two other counts. He had previously played for the charity, but on this occasion, he was only busking. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign had given him permission to use the banner but not to collect funds. Carpenter, known as a busker to the campaign, will be sentenced in January.

The passage describes a football match between Ipswich Town and Queens Park Rangers (QPR) in which Ipswich Town won 3-0. The first goal was scored by Grant Ward, the second by Luke Varney, and the third by Tom Lawrence. QPR's goalkeeper, Alex Smithies, made an error that led to the second goal. Ipswich Town's manager, Mick McCarthy, was pleased with the team's performance, particularly that of Luke Varney and Jonathan Douglas. QPR's manager, Ian Holloway, was disappointed with his team's performance, particularly after the second goal, and felt that his players needed to be mentally tougher. The win moved Ipswich Town up to 14th place in the league, above QPR who slipped to 15th.

The passage is about a 23-year-old cricketer named Wells who performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. Wells has expressed his excitement about joining the club, mentioning the positive and high-performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, a team in fifth place in National Two South, recently won against the third-placed Chinnor with a score of 29-12, marking their second consecutive win. According to Churcher, Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were key leaders in the team's performance. The front row and front five made a significant number of tackles, contributing to the team's success. The Reds will face seven teams that are currently below them in the table in their next eight games, as well as the league leaders, Old Elthamians. Churcher believes that while the team's performance against Chinnor was not perfect, it was a strong and determined effort. He emphasizes the importance of building on this performance in future games.

The police have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a Bangladeshi citizen, in connection with the rape of a 74-year-old nun in India. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata and is the sixth person to be arrested in this case. The police have identified eight suspects in total, with two still untraced. Nazrul has been accused of being the one who raped the nun during an attack on a convent school in Ranaghat town on 14 March. The attack, which also involved theft and vandalism, led to widespread outrage and street protests across India. Nazrul had reportedly fled to Bangladesh after the attack but was arrested upon his return to Kolkata.

The passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. The video discusses the reasons for changes in consumer buying habits, such as the introduction of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also explores the changing ownership and ranking of some of the biggest brands in the UK. The interactive elements of the video provide additional information on these topics, including the top 20 consumer brands in the UK, China's ownership of global brands, and tips on freezing food. The video is best viewed in full screen and can also be accessed in a non-interactive format.

The passage describes two incidents where individuals were deceived by people pretending to be from BT. The first incident involved a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills, and the second involved a woman in Stranraer. The perpetrators claimed to be from BT technical support and gained remote access to the victims' computers to steal money. The first incident occurred on September 15, and the second happened seven days later. Police are urging people to be cautious when receiving cold calls from individuals seeking remote access to their computers and to never provide banking details or account numbers over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, a team currently in third place in the Championship. He will make his debut as the team's leader in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday, before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, who has previously played for several teams during his 16-year career, has been replaced at his former assistant position at Swinton by Stuart Littler. The chairman of Featherstone, Mark Campbell, has expressed his excitement about Duffy's arrival and his belief in Duffy's ability to do a great job, despite the difficult circumstances he faced at Swinton.

The passage describes an incident where a horse rider was injured at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday around 12:50 GMT. The Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to the scene. The rider had sustained head injuries and was suffering from exposure due to lying unconscious on wet sand. The individual was treated at the scene and then airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further care.

The UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, utilizing satellite tracking of planes. This decision was made in response to the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted the limitations of the current ground-based radar tracking system. The new system will enable real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world, using automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions. The ITU has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes.

18-year-old Julian Hernandez, who went missing at the age of five, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. The father, 53, was arrested and is being held at a jail in Ohio. The FBI received a tip after the teenager faced issues while applying for college, which led to his identification. His mother has been informed. Bobby Hernandez is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's license in 2012. He is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected the father's involvement around the time of the boy's disappearance.

The passage describes a fire that occurred at a site run by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited in Duncan Street on March 2nd, which led to travel disruptions. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company's ability to accept waste after the incident. The fire service had visited the site nine times in the past year and had expressed concerns to the EA about the potential impact of a fire. Despite being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the company's permit was revoked by the EA, effective August 7th, and they are required to remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The Pro-Kremlin party, A Just Russia, has proposed two bills in response to the crisis in Ukraine, particularly in the Crimea region where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill would allow Russia to accept a territory whose people have expressed a clear desire to join Russia, even if the neighboring state is disintegrating. The second bill aims to expedite the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speaking ones, who are considered to be facing a "brown threat." The bill would waive certain requirements, such as the need to give up Ukrainian citizenship, and would shorten the waiting period for citizenship. Several Russian MPs and celebrities have traveled to Crimea in support of these initiatives.

The passage discusses the current struggles of the McLaren Formula 1 team, which has a rich history of success, including 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. The team's decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now they face problems with their Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Jenson Button, in their lineup, the team has not won a race since 2012. The team's history has been marked by cycles of triumph and decline, and they are currently in a down period. However, team boss Ron Dennis believes that success will return and that McLaren will be the next team to break Mercedes' dominance in F1.

Thomas Baker, also known as Tommy, was found with gunshot wounds to the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27th January. The 44-year-old later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men have been arrested in connection with the incident and remain in police custody. The police believe the suspects had been waiting outside the gym where Baker was before the shooting. A silver VW Polo, which left the scene at speed, is being sought by the police. Detectives are urging individuals who were captured on CCTV near the market to come forward as they may have crucial information.

The passage discusses five ways to enjoy Christmas online, including attending virtual church services through Everyday Church Online, playing the Bible-themed game Guardians of Ancora, watching nativity videos such as The Digital Story of the Nativity, reading the Manga Messiah, and engaging with religious communities on social media platforms. The virtual church services, held in a chat room, have attracted participants from 61 countries. The Guardians of Ancora game has been played by 45,000 users within four months of its release. The Digital Story of the Nativity video has been viewed nearly six million times. The Manga Messiah is available in 33 languages, and religious groups use social media platforms to connect with their communities.

The passage discusses an eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale regarding a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land for a development. The backers of the project, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered 320 hectares of replacement land. There are conflicting opinions from experts about the potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to conclude that the replacement land is of equal value, but they are not opposing the development. An ecology report from the developers claims a net gain in biodiversity, while the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and Welsh government ministers will have the final say.

The passage discusses a meeting of Chechen Muslim clerics on April 3, in response to a report by Novaya Gazeta on April 1 that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The clerics' resolution is interpreted by Novaya Gazeta as a call for reprisals against journalists. The Russian LGBT Network confirms the report's accuracy, stating that detainees were tortured. Chechnya's leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, denies the allegations. The passage also mentions that Chechens have been linked to the murders of two Novaya Gazeta reporters and opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. The LGBT Network is helping people flee Chechnya and may take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russian authorities fail to prosecute anyone.

The passage discusses the relationship between Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity. Investing Solutions receives housing benefit payments by providing accommodation for single homeless men, often in shared properties, and charging housing benefit for each individual rather than the property as a whole. Fresh Start Housing refers clients to Investing Solutions, and both organizations are based in the same building, with the same founder, Samir Patel. The arrangement is profitable for Investing Solutions, as they receive a significant portion of the housing benefit payments, while the property owners receive less. Some tenants have reported issues with the properties, and there are concerns about the ethics of the arrangement. Fresh Start Housing states that they are an independent charity and that the majority of properties are sourced from private landlords. The Department for Communities and Local Government states that local authorities are responsible for ensuring the proper use of taxpayers' money.

The passage is about a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and the Netherlands. GB, led by coach Joe Prunty and NBA player Ben Gordon (who scored 13 points), lost the game despite having a lead in the first three quarters. GB's Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points. The Dutch team, led by Worthy De Jong with 18 points, overtook GB in the last 10 minutes of the game. The game was a warm-up match before GB's Eurobasket qualifying campaign. Prunty was pleased with Gordon's contribution, who hit three three-pointers in a row in the third quarter.

The passage discusses the upcoming boxing match between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor, specifically focusing on the potential use of lighter gloves. The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) requires 10oz gloves for fights at 154 lbs, but both fighters have expressed interest in using 8oz gloves. The NAC will debate the matter on August 16th. The passage also mentions that McGregor, a UFC fighter, will be making his boxing debut against the undefeated Mayweather. The NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, has studied McGregor's fighting history and believes he is a worthy opponent. The passage also notes that McGregor's camp has hired boxing referee Joe Cortez to help prepare for the fight.

The Sunday Post, a newspaper based in Dundee, closed its London office on Fleet Street, which was once the hub of British journalism. At its peak, nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers had offices within a half-mile radius. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published in Fleet Street on 11 March 1702. The street was famous for its many bars and pubs, constantly occupied by journalists both socializing and seeking stories. The departure of the last two journalists from Fleet Street, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, marks the end of an era. The decline of Fleet Street began in 1986 when media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to a purpose-built complex in Wapping, east London. By 1988, most national newspapers had moved away from Fleet Street to other parts of London, adopting new computerized printing technology. The buildings that once housed the newspapers have since been repurposed.

The passage discusses a situation involving Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and her experiences with political criticism on Twitter. Rowling had previously donated money to the campaign against Scottish independence and the Labour party, which led to her receiving abusive comments, including being called a "traitor". She responded to the abuse by standing up to the bullies and blocking some Twitter users, who she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Despite the criticism, Rowling also engaged with other SNP supporters and found common political ground with them. The SNP went on to become the third largest party in the UK following the election.

The passage is a study conducted by the University of Edinburgh researchers, which found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. The study also identified that living in poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. Poorer young people were also about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. The study also found that people who lived in extreme poverty were much more likely to be the victims and perpetrators of crime. Gender was identified as one of the most powerful predictors of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls on average to engage in violent acts. The study has been funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation and the Scottish government. The Scottish government spokesman said that Scotland is becoming a safer place to live with recorded crime at a 41-year low, homicide figures at their lowest level in 39 years and 1,000 extra officers on our streets.

25-year-old Karl Haugh was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and has been remanded in custody. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. It is alleged that Mr Walsh and two other males entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee after 01:00 on Sunday, called to houses looking for Mr Haugh, and a fight ensued where weapons were used. Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. A knife handle and a blade were recovered at the scene. The case has been adjourned until 14 August.

The Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, in May 2014, suggesting he had harassed and shot people. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue. The apology must be posted on Twitter. Mr. Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years and has a clear MoD record. The court was told that the insurance firm which indemnifies MLAs at Stormont has refused to cover Flanagan in respect of any compensation and costs in this case.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 employees and a history dating back to 1874, has increased its production of sweaters to 9,500 per week, up from 7,500 last year. This boost in production is due to better than expected sales of their new Hawick Knitwear-branded range, which launched in January, and growth in their established business of supplying private label customers. The company sells its products in various European countries, including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as in markets outside Europe such as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Managing director Benny Hartop, who bought the company in November last year, attributes the success to the dedicated staff and expresses optimism for the future.

The passage describes a court case involving Brian Wright, who is accused of causing serious injury by dangerous driving to Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady who was hit by Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and didn't see Mrs. Blackburn, who was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. The incident occurred when the traffic lights were red, and Wright's VW Golf failed to stop. Mrs. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now being treated in residential care. Wright expressed his remorse for the incident but denies the charges against him. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a Nato anti-submarine warfare exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," in response to increased Russian submarine activity in the same waters. The exercise involves 10 Nato warships, including the USS Vicksburg and the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for the German U-boat U33, which is acting as the enemy. The exercise highlights the challenges of locating submarines and the growing concern about Russia's increasing military strength, particularly in submarine development. Russia has a fleet of around 60 submarines, and has recently launched a new "quiet" submarine. The exercise also highlights Britain's lack of maritime patrol aircraft, a significant gap in the UK's defenses.

The passage describes the violence and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, particularly in the Equatoria states, that has led to a mass exodus of refugees into neighboring Uganda. The UN reports that 340,000 people have fled to Uganda in 2016, with an average of 2,500 South Sudanese becoming refugees daily. The violence is described as targeting civilians along ethnic lines, with the Dinka tribe allegedly targeting Equatorians and Nuer. Refugees report killings, rape, and other forms of violence, and Uganda is struggling to cope with the influx of refugees despite its generous approach. The passage also highlights the trauma experienced by children, with many of them becoming orphans due to the violence.

The passage discusses the upcoming English super-middleweight championship bout between McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer with a 8-0-1 record, and Jahmaine Smyle, scheduled for 12 November at York Hall. McKenzie, the son of former British and European champion Clinton and trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie, turned professional in 2013 after quitting football.

The passage discusses the funding and plans for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital in England, which is part of a £330m investment in new NHS facilities. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is described as cramped and outdated by Matron Sue Taylor. The total cost of the project is £33m, with the remaining balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is planned to be built on Bowers Lane, aiming for completion by autumn 2014, subject to planning permission. In the past five years, three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and work on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton has also begun. Dr Donal Hynes, a Bridgwater GP, believes the new hospital will significantly improve patient care.

The passage describes a fatal shooting of a man in Sheffield, near a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe. The victim was found with a gunshot wound to the chest and was taken to the hospital but did not survive. The incident occurred near a black Mercedes the man had been driving, and it happened during a family celebration. There have been several shootings in Sheffield recently, but this is the first one in the Upperthorpe area. Previous incidents have occurred in the north of the city, including in Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green.

The passage describes the activities of three groups of hackers involved in the Ukraine conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are pro-Ukrainian and have carried out DDoS attacks, hacked into CCTV systems, and disrupted separatist funding. Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western group that supports the separatists and has hacked Ukrainian government websites, disrupted electronic vote-counting systems, and leaked Ukrainian defense ministry data. Anonymous International is a Russian activist group that has published leaked documents from the Kremlin and material covering Ukraine. The group's access to information is unclear, as it is unknown whether they obtain material through hacking or are given it by Kremlin insiders. The passage also notes that some media reports suggest that Ukraine's security services have used information obtained by hackers to direct artillery fire, but officials deny this.

The passage describes the emotional farewell speeches of Presiding officer Tricia Marwick, veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and former First Minister Alex Salmond, who are all standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Salmond used his speech to reiterate his belief in Scotland's diversity and the need for greater responsibility in governance, while McNeil warned of the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, is also leaving Holyrood and joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. The presiding officer was moved to tears by McNeil's speech and thanked Salmond for his service to Scotland.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is seeking to gather evidence from older people, their friends, and families about their experiences in residential care. This information will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales, examining factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner aims to highlight good care practices and address the impact of poor care on older people. The review is part of the commissioner's broader work to ensure that the voices of older people and their loved ones are heard. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expresses concern about the lack of provider representation on the main advisory panel.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000, resulting in a total of £3.5m, in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m decrease in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various agricultural sectors and operates 19 shops across Scotland, experienced growth in international sales during this period, both in Europe and in new markets. The company acknowledged the unpredictability of the agricultural outlook and the challenges faced in the past 12-18 months, but expressed confidence in the industry's resilience and their ability to adapt to potential challenges brought about by Brexit.

The body of a man in his 70s was discovered at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. Another man, in his 80s, was taken to the hospital. Police are looking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the incident. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying, straight, collar-length hair, and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt. Anyone with information is urged to contact the police or Crimestoppers.

The passage discusses a speech by David Lipton, the second-in-command at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), in which he expressed concerns about the weakening global economy and described the current situation as a "delicate juncture." The IMF is likely to downgrade its forecast for global growth, currently at 3.4%, in its next economic predictions release in April. This outlook is partly due to weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, where exports have dropped by 25% compared to the previous year. The slowdown in China's growth has ongoing implications for various businesses and industries.

The new vessel at Cowes has been experiencing numerous issues since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions due to training issues. The council has ordered a review of the project and has made the crossing free until 2 July to allow for feedback and in recognition of the problems. Some local businesses have suffered losses due to the issues with the ferry, and compensation is being considered. The council has authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete, and the grounding issues have been addressed.

A fatal multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was killed in the incident, and a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed until early evening for investigation.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding Matching Models in London, an international temp agency, which has been criticized for discriminatory job advertisements. The agency's job postings, such as one for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, have been deemed unlawful and demeaning to women by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC). The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends their practices, stating that looks are important to their clients. The agency's hiring practices are being investigated by the EHRC, and employment lawyers have deemed the advertisements as potentially discriminatory. The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various factors, including age, sexual orientation, marital status, disability, race, and religion. Despite the criticism, Matching Models continues to operate and serve high-profile clients.

The passage describes a shooting that occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was an office assistant at the school and is accused of shooting two students, 18-year-old Gautami, who died, and another student, Sirisha, who was severely injured but is now out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt. The motive for the shooting is not yet clear. Incidents of gun crime at schools and colleges in India are very rare. India has strict gun control laws, but firearms are still used to settle feuds. In 2007, a 14-year-old schoolboy was shot dead by two fellow students at a school campus near Delhi.

The passage describes the findings of a study by the advocacy group Glaad, which analyzed shows from June 2016 to May 2017 and found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, including a record high of 16 transgender characters. However, the report also noted a significant number of deaths among lesbian and bisexual female characters, sparking criticism. The study also found a high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, due in part to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis commented on the progress being made, but also emphasized that numbers are only part of the story.

The passage discusses Conservative MP David Mackintosh's decision to step down as the MP for Northampton South. This announcement came after a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC had reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC, when Mackintosh was the leader of the borough council, had gone missing. The loan was intended for rebuilding Sixfields stadium and developing nearby land. The MP has denied any wrongdoing in this matter. The loan is currently under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities, and a majority of his party's local executive council had indicated they would vote to deselect him. Mackintosh had previously stated his intention to stand for re-election, but has now decided it is time for his constituents to have a new representative.

The passage discusses the case of Roy Oliver, a police officer who shot and killed a 15-year-old boy, Jordan Edwards, in April in Balch Springs, Texas. Oliver was indicted for murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official, as the car full of teenagers he fired into included two of the victim's brothers. The police initially claimed the car was reversing aggressively towards the officer, but footage showed it driving forward, away from him. Oliver was fired from the police force for policy violations. The trial date has not been set, and Oliver is currently free on bail. The district attorney stated that justice is proceeding effectively and thoroughly. The teenager was described positively by his coach, and if convicted, Oliver would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas county since 1973. A lawyer for the Edwards family expressed caution about the indictment.

The passage discusses the decision of Melania Trump, the wife of the president-elect, to not move to the White House immediately after the inauguration, but to wait until the end of her son Barron's school year. This decision has been met with criticism, but it is not without precedent. Only two other First Ladies in history have not resided in the White House during their husbands' terms. The role of the First Lady is largely ceremonial, involving hosting and attending functions, and often includes supporting various causes. Melania Trump has indicated that her top priority will be her son, and she has shown interest in tackling cyber-bullying. The passage also discusses the experiences of other presidential children who have lived in the White House, and the efforts of past presidents to maintain a normal family life in the White House.

The passage discusses an investigation into the death of a 72-year-old man in Inverness, which occurred on October 27th. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, has been tasked to examine the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is fully cooperating with the investigation and awaiting its findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service has instructed the PIRC to investigate the initial police response to the man's call, and a report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course.

The UK Met Office has issued a yellow wind warning for several counties in Wales, including Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) are expected, particularly in the west and in an unusual easterly direction, which could lead to travel disruption on roads and at sea. A tree was brought down in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, causing the closure of Telford Road.

The Giants, led by player-coach Derrick Walser, had a short-lived lead in their match against the Panthers with a goal from Walser and an opposing goal from Jeff Dimmen, ending the first period 1-1. The second period saw Mike Forney and Andy Bohmback scoring for their respective teams, keeping the game tied. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored for the Giants, but David Ling of the Panthers managed to score one back. The final score was 4-3 for the Giants. The teams are set to meet again in a second match. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

The 2016 Chinese Grand Prix was marked by a series of incidents, including a first-lap collision involving Lewis Hamilton, Sebastian Vettel, and Kimi Raikkonen. Hamilton, who started from the back, suffered a broken front wing and had to make five pit stops. Despite the collision, Vettel managed to finish second, while Raikkonen recovered to fifth place. The incident between Vettel and Raikkonen was caused by Daniil Kvyat, who was confronted by Vettel after the race. Hamilton's progress was hindered by damage to his car, and he was unable to recover as much ground as the Ferraris. Nico Rosberg won the race, extending his lead in the championship over Hamilton to 36 points. No driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to go on to claim the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, has publicly revealed his homosexuality, becoming the most prominent footballer to do so. The announcement has been met with support from his former teammates, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as leading figures in German football administration. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a significant moment in Germany, where homophobia in football has been a persistent issue. The former footballer has expressed his hope that his decision will advance discussion on the topic. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay German politician Volker Beck have also praised Hitzlsperger's courage and expressed hope that his announcement will encourage others to do the same.

The passage discusses Brighton midfielder Steve Sidwell's, 34, desire to sign a new contract with the team following their promotion to the Premier League. Sidwell has made 32 appearances this season and believes he has earned the opportunity to play at the top level again. He previously played in the Premier League with several teams and has made a significant impact on Brighton's promotion. With his current contract set to expire, Sidwell hopes to negotiate a new deal to continue playing with Brighton in the Premier League.

The Seasiders (Blackpool) scored the first goal in the 12th minute with a close-range effort from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized in the 17th minute through Kurtis Guthrie after a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Colchester's George Elokobi and Guthrie missed opportunities to retake the lead before halftime. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a chance to clinch the win in the 75th minute. Colchester's Sean Murray was sent off in injury time for a dangerous tackle on Jim McAlister. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The passage discusses the transfer of a 29-year-old player from the 'Sky Blues', a team that was relegated from League One, to the 'U's'. The player, likely a footballer given the context, made 37 appearances last season. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. His debut for the 'U's' could be in the EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. The 'U's' lost their first match of the season to Accrington 3-1.

The passage discusses the plan to build a permanent memorial for PC Keith Palmer and other officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty. The UK Police Memorial Trust has appealed for £1.5m towards the construction of the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial, expected to be completed by 2019, will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial.

The passage discusses Manchester United's 1-0 win over Sunderland, which kept them 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left. Manager Alex Ferguson is focused on the upcoming games, including the derby against Manchester City, and is not concerned with their lead. The team has won 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and is aiming to better Chelsea's record 95-point haul in 2005. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries suffered by Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea. The team showed determined defending and courage to secure the win against Sunderland.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK, with CEO Mr Schmidt stating that the company pays the legally required amount of taxes. Between 2006 and 2011, Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes. Schmidt mentioned that it is up to the government to change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more taxes. The passage also mentions that the head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, Margaret Hodge, suggested a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. The EU has agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities". Schmidt has previously argued for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are taken, not where products are consumed, and called for a debate on international tax reform.

The NHS regulator, NHS Improvement, is seeking to reduce the agency staff spending by £1bn, from the current £3.6bn, by the end of this financial year. A cap was introduced in October, limiting the amount hospitals can pay for agency staff, which has saved £600m so far. However, the NHS is still behind schedule in meeting the target. The cap applies to all staff, including doctors, nurses, and administration staff, except for senior managers. NHS Improvement stated that the progress is promising, but more needs to be done. The agency bill is falling, but it is unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has increased. NHS Improvement will start publishing league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust.

The Longford Town Centre, once intended to be a symbol of commerce, now stands as a reminder of Ireland's economic downturn. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien who runs a men's clothing shop, have faced difficulties but are starting to see improvements. The opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the current coalition's handling of the midlands' situation, suggesting that funds allocated for water meters should be used for broadband improvement. They also accuse the government of negligence, stating that the IDA hasn't brought any potential clients to Longford in over four years. The government, however, points to the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, which could create about 1,000 jobs when it opens in 2019. The message from the midlands is that while there are signs of economic recovery, more needs to be done.

The Indian Premier League (IPL) tournament concludes on May 29 in the same stadium where it began. Eight teams are participating, each facing the others twice, with the top four teams advancing to the play-offs. The leading run-scorers are Warner, Kohli, and De Villiers, and the players with the most sixes are Warner, De Villiers, and Kohli. The highest score in an innings is held by De Kock, Warner, and Gambhir. The most wickets have been taken by McClenaghan, Kumar, and Rahman. Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The passage also includes a schedule of upcoming matches, including dates, times, and teams.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, which pose environmental problems as they often end up in landfills and waterways. To encourage reuse and reduce waste, a 5p charge will be implemented for plastic bags in England starting October. Similar measures in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have led to a decrease in bag usage. The goal is to decrease bag disposal and benefit the environment.

The passage describes severe weather conditions in Wales on Friday, including high winds that caused a school roof to be damaged, power cuts for hundreds of homes, and travel disruptions such as train delays and ferry cancellations. A 'be aware' wind warning was in effect until midnight, and high winds also led to the closure of some tourist attractions and the postponement of a festive event. Despite some restrictions being lifted, a blustery forecast was expected for the Christmas weekend.

Michael B. Jordan has been cast in the upcoming Black Panther film, reuniting with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He is excited to work with Coogler again and with his other co-stars, including Oscar winner Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who currently plays Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Nyong'o also played a CGI character in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film is set to be released in February 2018. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot.

The passage discusses the planned restoration of a theatre and BBC studios, located in the eastern end of Alexandra Palace, which was founded in 1875. The goal is to use the theatre for various performances and events, and the studios for broadcasting. The project is part of a larger initiative to transform Alexandra Palace into a cultural hub. The restoration includes the refurbishment of the glazed east court, which will become a public space and exhibition area. The Heritage Lottery Fund has contributed £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The total cost of the east wing refurbishment is £26.6m. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, still retains much of its original decor and stage machinery. It was originally designed to host a variety of entertainment, including opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings. The restoration project aims to reopen the theatre in 2018.

The passage discusses the retirement of footballer James Milner from international duty with England. Milner, a former Manchester City player, made his senior debut in 2009 and earned 61 caps for England, participating in several World Cups and European Championships. However, he only played for three minutes during Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps and scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. He made the decision to retire from international duty, wishing the team and new manager Sam Allardyce success in the future.

The passage describes a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, in which the Smith family's house was completely destroyed. The fire was caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, and the family's dog and cats did not survive. The family was able to escape unharmed due to the quick thinking of the son, David, who woke everyone up when he saw the flames. The community has rallied behind the family, providing them with clothes, shoes, and other necessities. The fire alarm did not go off during the incident.

The passage discusses the potential takeover of West Ham United, a Premier League club, by an energy drinks giant. The deal is reported to be worth £200m. David Sullivan and David Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010, valuing the club at £105m, and now own over 85% of it. The club's move to London Stadium in August has also attracted interest from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan had previously stated that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but the intention was for ownership to pass to their children.

The passage is about the MTV Movie Awards, which is a fan-voted awards ceremony. The night's big winner was "The Fault in Our Stars," with its star Shailene Woodley winning multiple awards. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for "American Sniper," Channing Tatum for "22 Jump Street," and Meryl Streep for "Into the Woods." The ceremony also served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award, and Robert Downey Jr. was honored with the Generation Award. The event featured clips from upcoming movies such as "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."

The passage discusses the loan of Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old footballer, from Aberdeen (The Dons) to Dundee United. Smith has scored 5 goals this season. He debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and has made 89 appearances, scoring 4 times. Jack Ross, St Mirren's boss, has described Smith's acquisition as 'brilliant' and 'a good fit', providing the team with another option in the attacking area. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

The passage states that Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes now that the weather is warm enough. The goal is to fix approximately 145 potholes per day over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair damaged drainage systems and clear gutters.

In December 2016, six workers employed by Wood Group on the Thistle platform, operated by EnQuest, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during planned shutdown activities. The exposure was less than 1% of the level reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but EnQuest still informed the HSE. The workers were removing a piece of pipework without proper personal protective equipment (PPE), as it was assumed to be clear. EnQuest has taken additional precautionary steps to prevent such exposure in the future. Wood Group downmanned their employees from the platform for medical assessments and supported a joint investigation. The workers now face cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests. Steve Innes, a rigging supervisor, claimed that EnQuest failed in its duty of care and that he has struggled to find more work since raising concerns. The HSE has been made aware of the incident but has not carried out an investigation.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007 for $650,000. The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the said sculpture. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, southern India. The decision to return the item was made after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government body, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI requested the return of the sculpture in May. The ACM bought 30 objects from the dealer, but none of the others are thought to be listed as stolen. The museum plans to take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

The passage describes a magnitude-4.8 earthquake that struck near the city of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in several cities, including Milan and Florence, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake was followed by several aftershocks, and phone lines and power supplies were affected in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution, and the event brought back memories of the deadly 2009 earthquake in L'Aquila, where six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing a falsely reassuring statement about the risk of earthquakes.

The passage, dated 8 September 2016, describes an event where Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, successfully grew a fruit in South Yorkshire's climate, which he had previously been dubious about. The fruit was not yet ripe enough to eat at the time of the report.

The release of the game by Rockstar has been postponed from January 27 to March 24 to allow for additional testing and polishing. The delay is said to be in the best interests of the game and its fans. Meanwhile, online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version of GTA V will offer greater levels of detail, with 1080p at 60fps, and up to 4K resolution with support for triple monitor configurations. The game's minimum specifications required to run on PC have also been published. Grand Theft Auto V was the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in revenue in just three days after its release in September 2013.

The 76-year-old artist, Simpson, has won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work 'Squint (19)', a difficult-to-look-at painting that depicts a leper squint, a hole in the side of medieval churches for outcasts to participate in services. Simpson, who has been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, plans to spend the prize money on art materials. Judge Ansel Krut praised the painting for its subtlety and minimalism, stating that it gradually builds a picture when one spends time with it. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked with gunfire and firebombs, resulting in shattered windows and a small fire that was quickly extinguished. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously at both buildings, which are 12 miles apart, and no casualties were reported. Police have cordoned off the area and are searching for the four masked assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. Both newspapers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. This incident follows a previous attack on the daily Hurriyet's offices last September by pro-government protesters.

The passage states that a 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will be joining Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. The player had been on loan at Crawley for the first half of the season, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. His transfer will be official on January 1st, marking the first signing for the Mariners by Bignot.

The passage discusses Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's comments regarding the England national team's managerial position and the potential candidacy of Gareth Southgate, who is currently serving as interim manager. Wenger, whose contract with Arsenal runs until the summer, has been linked to the England job but remains focused on his current role. Southgate, 46, will have the opportunity to prove his competency in the upcoming World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly against Spain. Additionally, Wenger confirmed that Arsenal is planning to offer a new contract to 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin, who has been linked with a move to Barcelona and Manchester City. Wenger also provided an update on midfielder Aaron Ramsey's injury, stating that he will miss one or two more games.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker on Thursday around 13:45 GMT, leading to a joint inquiry by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive. The company, Fruehauf, is fully cooperating with the investigation.

The passage discusses the resolution of a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight vessels, Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck. The crew, many of whom are non-UK residents, were reportedly paid less than £4 an hour. The new charter arrangement, proposed by Transport Minister Humza Yousaf, will see the contracted services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. This change will ensure that all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. The freight vessels are part of the Northern Isles contract, a heavily subsidized route operated by Serco Northlink since 2012.

64-year-old Ken Dickie passed away in the hospital on May 14, following an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole on May 7. The incident occurred after Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. Mitchell had admitted to common assault in relation to a confrontation with Mr. Dickie and, along with his mother, attempted to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. They will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter, passed away in London at the age of 66 after a short battle with cancer. He wrote several hit songs, including "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," and "Thriller" for Michael Jackson, and "Boogie Nights" for his band Heatwave. Temperton was known for his low profile and was nicknamed "The Invisible Man." He started his career in a frozen food factory before joining Heatwave and later working with Quincy Jones on Michael Jackson's albums. His songs have also been recorded by other artists, and he won a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on "Birdland." A private funeral has taken place.

The passage describes a discovery made by a team of researchers, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, in the western Brazilian Amazon. They found ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, which were concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation allowed their discovery. The team, which also includes researchers from the universities of Exeter, Reading, and Brazil's SÃ£o Paulo, BelÃ©m, investigated more than 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs". The function of these sites is still not well understood, but they are thought to have been used as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America or Britain's Stonehenge. Dr Loader analyzed soil samples from the geoglyphs and found that they were constructed among taller vegetation, which suggests that they were not visible above the forest canopy. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems before the arrival of Europeans, but were instead transformed by humans through the use of "agroforestry" practices, which involved concentrating on economically valuable trees such as palms. The team suggests that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may still reflect these ancient practices.

22-year-old Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, currently ranked 12th in the world, won his first-round match at the Shanghai Masters against world number 29 Sam Querrey with a score of 6-4, 6-4. The match lasted 53 minutes. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, admitted to feeling tired and bored during the match due to the long travel and lack of sleep. Last year, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst at the same tournament.

The passage discusses the call from scientists and charities for the HPV vaccine to be given to boys in Wales to protect them from head and neck cancers, as the virus is sexually transmitted and can cause cancer in both men and women. The vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect them from cervical cancer, with 85% of girls in Wales having been vaccinated. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

15-year-old Jak Trueman, a pupil at West Calder High School, passed away from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He had been documenting his life and treatment on social media, including his Facebook page 'Jak's Journey', which gained over 28,000 Likes. Jak's story of his fight against cancer and his positive attitude touched many people, and he met several Rangers FC stars during his treatment. Despite feeling unwell, Jak managed to attend his school prom for a short time, where he was presented with the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. After learning that his cancer had spread throughout his body, Jak and his family urged people to donate to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. A fundraising football match is planned for Sunday at the Energy Assets Arena, home of Livingston FC.

The passage describes a soccer match between Egypt and Uganda, which Egypt won 1-0 with a goal scored by El Said in the 89th minute. The game was mostly uneventful with few chances for either side, and Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside. The win means Egypt will play Ghana in their final group stage match, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. The passage also mentions that Ghana secured their place in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 victory over Mali earlier on the same day.

The passage discusses the plans of Lancashire County Council to build a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town without its own station and one of the largest in the north west of England. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, has identified a preferred location for the station on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, both of which are currently unused. The decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail of three potential sites. The new station could provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The council now plans to start the process of acquiring the relevant land.
A warehouse near Ashbourne was searched on Saturday morning, resulting in the discovery of plants in a sophisticated grow house. A man in his late 40s was apprehended at the scene.

The passage describes an incident in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, where a 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured after being dragged by the neck through several streets. The woman, who is of Kurdish origin, underwent emergency surgery and was taken to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, also of Kurdish origin, later turned himself in to the authorities. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police have appealed for witnesses to come forward.

The passage discusses a study on pay rise requests and outcomes for male and female workers. The research found no evidence to support the idea that women are less likely to ask for a pay rise than men. However, when comparing like-for-like male and female workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they asked. The study also found no evidence to support the idea that women are more wary of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The research took into account various factors, such as the size of the employer, industry, and qualifications. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The researchers were surprised by the findings and suggested that there may be some element of pure discrimination against women. The study also found that women and men under 40 both ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, which could indicate that negotiating behavior has started to change.

The Oxford City Council has been unable to find a suitable new burial site despite searching for many years. The money allocated for this purpose has been used for site investigations, but all council-owned sites identified have been deemed unsuitable due to various reasons such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After they are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22, will offer visitors an augmented reality experience via an app. This app will allow users to access online information from signs, posters, and other items on the festival site. The online material will include videos and band interviews. The festival's lineup includes acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and get a sense of its atmosphere. The app's content will be updated in the lead-up to and during the event, providing information, interviews, and ticket purchasing options.

The 10-year-old horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, as confirmed by the British Horseracing Authority. The horse had no significant underlying health issues, but had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, which had seen him over-heat and "wobble" on his feet. However, he had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms of post-race ataxia on the day of his death. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described as the "horse of a lifetime" by his trainer, Oliver Sherwood.

15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now 34 and identifying as Davina, was charged with raping the girl. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, denied the charge and will be sentenced on March 4. Judge Ian Pearson remanded Ayrton into custody, stating that she would likely be held at a male prison in Winchester. The court heard that Ayrton attempted to commit suicide last summer and had not made any physical changes or enhancements to her body. The victim said she had only drunk a can and a half of Foster's and clearly recollected the events. In 2014, Ayrton told a worker at the care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, about the attack.

The passage describes a tennis match in which Serbian players lost to Brazilian players, Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares, with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This loss occurred after Novak Djokovic, the world number one player from Serbia, was previously defeated in the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, aged 29, had also experienced a surprising loss at Wimbledon in July, where he was beaten by American Sam Querrey. However, he later reclaimed his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

20+ competitors, including entrants from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, will participate in the chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, on Saturday. The event allows only the use of chainsaws to carve logs into various shapes, such as animals and people. The reigning champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will attempt to defend his title and keep the Claymore Trophy.

The passage discusses the rugby player, Webb, who has been out of play since September due to a foot injury. He is expected to return to the field at the beginning of February, just in time for the Six Nations tournament. Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region. He is currently undergoing a pre-season training stage to regain his fitness.

The incident involved a failed attempt to smuggle 58lb of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco, resulting in the arrest of four individuals. Two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, were encountered by US border agents near Sumas, Washington, carrying backpacks containing the drugs. One of them fired a weapon at the agents and fled but was later arrested by Canadian police. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their involvement in the smuggling attempt. They face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known for smuggling activities, and such prosecutions are common in the US attorney's practice for the Western District of Washington.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The true number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. The abuse has led to children as young as seven feeling tormented, abused, and scared to go to school. The charity states that online trolls are causing misery and humiliation for thousands of children. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, has called for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children from cyber-bullying, as it often does not stop without intervention. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance. Young people who have experienced bullying suggest standing up for oneself, not engaging with the bully, and seeking help from others as ways to deal with bullying.

The UN Security Council passed a resolution, supported by the US, calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which are considered illegal under international law. Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu rejected the resolution and accused the US of helping to draft it. In response, Israel has summoned the ambassadors of the US and other countries, recalled its ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had planned to authorize 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, but the vote has been postponed at the request of the prime minister's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington. US Secretary of State John Kerry is expected to give a speech outlining his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict. The Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas has said the resolution "paves the way" for an upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France.

The Queen of the United Kingdom, Elizabeth II, is turning 90 years old. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited a Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor to mark the occasion. A new picture of the Queen, the Prince of Wales, Prince William, and Prince George has been released for stamps to celebrate the Queen's birthday. Prince William, in an interview, praised the Queen's service and commitment, saying she has been a guiding example of what a good monarch should be. The Queen's birthday will be celebrated with various events, including a ceremony to officially open a new bandstand, a lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama, and the lighting of a beacon setting in train a series of more than 900 beacons across the UK and around the world. The Queen celebrates two birthdays each year, her actual birthday on 21 April and her official birthday on a Saturday in June. The BBC has been criticized by republican pressure group Republic for its coverage of the Queen's birthday.

The passage describes a football match between Cheltenham Town and West Ham United, which ended in a 2-0 victory for West Ham. The Premier League side took control of the game with two quick goals in the first half, one from Diafra Sakho and the other from Andre Ayew. Cheltenham, a League Two side, had a few good chances but were unable to score. The hosts made several changes to their lineup following recent losses in the Premier League, while Cheltenham were unchanged from their previous league defeat. The result means that all League Two teams have now been eliminated from the EFL Cup.

The passage describes an incident where a motorcyclist, Aidan McNicholl, died after a collision with a VW Transporter driven by Andreas Werner on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Werner, who failed to notice the motorcyclist while turning right, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and disqualified from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not see the value in Werner being imprisoned, and the defendant expressed remorse for his actions.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is a British jihadist who traveled to Syria in January 2014. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in their propaganda efforts, including videos, appeals for donations, and tours of fighters' quarters. Khawaja returned to the UK in June 2014, attempting to sneak back in undetected. He faked his own death online and was arrested upon his arrival at Dover. Khawaja has admitted to four offenses, including engaging in conduct in preparation for terrorism and attending a place used for terrorist training. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja was considered dangerous and was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects while on remand.

The passage discusses the signing of Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old footballer, by Barnsley. Jackson scored four goals in 36 games last season while playing for Wrexham, a team that finished eighth in the league. This signing makes him Barnsley's third acquisition for the upcoming season. The team's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson for his speed and ability to challenge defenders. Jackson had declined a contract extension offer from Wrexham for the next season.

The National Trust has been clearing away sealed detergent bottles that have been washing up on Poldhu Cove in Cornwall since Sunday, believed to have come from a container that fell off a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated that there is currently no concrete evidence linking the bottles to the MV Blue Ocean, which lost a container of 'Vanish' detergent. The incident has raised concerns about the impact on sensitive marine life, and the public has been advised to keep away from any bottles that wash up. The National Trust, Cornwall Council, Maritime and Coastguard Agency, and Natural England are monitoring the situation.

The passage describes a traffic incident that took place on the A9 near Berriedale, Caithness around 2 PM. The crash resulted in several people receiving minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were implemented. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

The passage is about Dorian Dervite, a French center-back who played a significant role in helping Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion last season. Dervite, who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, made 14 appearances in the 2016-2017 season. He has made a total of 83 appearances for the club across all competitions. The passage also mentions that Dervite has followed other players like David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing new contracts with Bolton after their promotion to the Championship.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have recently teamed up to inflict defeats on the government regarding the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, their cooperation ended when MPs rejected those amendments, with the Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source in the Lords accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" and giving people "false hope," while the Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and "lining up with the Conservatives as they drive forward with a hard Brexit." The two parties have a history of forming alliances on various issues, but there are now "residual tensions" between them.

The passage discusses the topic of defense and its lack of prominence in the political parties' priorities for the upcoming election. The public's concern for defense is low, and the military has faced budget cuts, reducing the size of the regular Army and the number of warships and fast jet squadrons. The UK has fallen to sixth place in defense spending, and there is a lack of commitment to spend 2% of the nation's wealth on defense. The passage also mentions the potential for further cuts in defense spending, the debate over the renewal of Britain's nuclear deterrent, and the challenges of manning and equipping the new aircraft carriers.

The Spanish champions, FC Barcelona, have paid £48.6m for Brazilian striker Neymar from Santos. The transfer includes a signing-on fee of £34m for Neymar's parents and a five-year deal with wages. The total cost of the transfer, including agents' fees and this latest tax payment, will be £106.8m. Barcelona denies any wrongdoing in the transfer and insists they have met all fiscal obligations. However, a judge in Spain has ruled that investigations into the transfer will continue due to sufficient evidence. Barcelona's president, Sandro Rosell, resigned last month following accusations of misappropriating money, but he denies any wrongdoing. Neymar has scored 7 goals in 18 league appearances for Barcelona this season.

27-year-old Michael Luciw from Nottingham died in a car accident caused by a driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, driving on the wrong side of the motorway. Michael's family suggests that retired people should undergo regular driving tests to ensure their safety on the road. Age UK emphasizes the importance of older people being able to drive for as long as possible, while the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) states that there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years and disclose any medical conditions that might affect their driving.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the use of transvaginal mesh implants in Scotland, with many women reporting debilitating side effects. Two patients on the original review group resigned in protest over what they perceived as a watered-down report. The Scottish government has appointed Alison Britton, a professor of healthcare and medical law, to examine the final report. The report, which concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse, has been met with criticism from some campaigners and patients. The health secretary, Shona Robison, confirmed that the report's recommendations would continue to be implemented, despite calls for an all-out ban. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for the lack of consensus around the report. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, with some suffering painful and debilitating complications. There are currently over 400 women taking legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers as a result of mesh implant surgery.

23-year-old Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5,000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan had initially raised concerns about the race meeting the criteria for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's ability to win world medals and suggested that she has the potential to run even faster. Muir also broke her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris in August and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

The passage describes the equestrian event at the Rio Olympics where Jung won the gold medal riding Sam, a replacement for Fischertakinou. France's Astier Nicolas won silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt, despite a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase, finished 12th due to a disappointing cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The article also mentions about Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics where one can meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse.

The passage describes a tennis match between Andy Murray and Fabio Fognini at a Grand Slam tournament. Murray won the match 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, securing his place in the last 16 for the 11th time.
