The match was tense and lasted for 2 hours and 39 minutes, with Murray clinching the win at 20:57 BST. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to seal the victory. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round. The passage also mentions that fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week of the tournament for the first time with a win over Maria Sakkari of Greece.

The passage describes a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on October 6, 2014, which led to the discovery of alcohol being served outside of licensing hours. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and another individual, James Thomas, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside of licensing hours. The defense solicitor acknowledged that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to. The judge ordered the closure of the bar for three months and fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000, expressing concern that he could not impose a custodial sentence. Ms. O'Neill was noted to have an "appalling record."

The passage discusses a speech by Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, in which he encouraged voters to support any candidate they believe in, regardless of party affiliation. This statement has caused controversy, with some interpreting it as a call to vote for nationalist parties. Nesbitt has since clarified his remarks, stating that he would prefer to partner with the SDLP over Sinn Féin. The Ulster Unionists' manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', focuses on issues such as healthcare, policing, infrastructure, LGBT rights, and Brexit. The party also calls for reform at Stormont, including measures to address the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. Despite the controversy, Nesbitt remains confident in his position and the support of his party members.

The passage discusses the Justice Minister of Northern Ireland, Claire Sugden, confirming that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, which would bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales in providing automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses. This move, dubbed 'Turing's Law', is named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing and would allow for posthumous pardons as well as pardons for living gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offenses, with the goal of implementing arrangements as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales. The motion will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

23-year-old Laura Muir from Kinross set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60. She now holds the Scottish records for both the 1500m and mile. Muir finished second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon in the race. This performance moved her to the second spot on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who finished fifth in last year's World Championships, started her season with an 800m victory in France and aims to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June. She fits her training around her veterinary studies and recently completed her fourth year of vet school. Yvonne Murray's husband, Tom Mooney, congratulated Muir on her achievement.
The passage mentions that certain Scottish beaches have been ranked as "most excellent" for their water quality, and it includes several pictures from these beaches.

The Russian state is the likely sponsor of the plot to kill Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian spy who died in London in 2006 after drinking tea containing a fatal dose of radioactive polonium-210. The two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive for the murder, but the Russian state had "reasons aplenty" for wishing him harm. The fact that polonium caused his death indicates some form of Russian state participation. Litvinenko had defected to the UK in 2000 and accused the FSB of corruption and murdering political opponents, which could have been seen as "akin to treachery". He had also made many personal attacks on Russian President Vladimir Putin. The two suspects left a "trail of polonium" behind and have no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Attempts to extradite them have failed and they remain in Russia. The risk to the general public in London from polonium radiation will never be known, and Litvinenko had been poisoned twice in the run-up to his death. The inquiry into his death has been adjourned until Friday.

26-year-old Steve Smith will take over as the captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing Michael Clarke who is retiring after the Ashes. Smith, who already leads the one-day side, will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Smith has played in 32 Tests for his country, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Warner has been given the vice-captain's role despite a history of disciplinary problems. They will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test at the Oval, which starts on 20 August.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron, who has previously refused to answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, has stated that he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and defending equal marriage is a top priority for him. He also expressed his desire to extend marital rights for transgender people, specifically addressing the issue of the spousal veto. In 2007, Farron voted against the Equality Bill, which would have made it harder for businesses to discriminate against gay people, due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties." However, he maintains that he is in favor of equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

The French company Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. However, Accord Healthcare has announced plans to use the same plant for its pharmaceutical production, with the intention of offering many of these jobs to former Sanofi employees. This development is expected to have a significantly positive impact on the local economy and strengthen the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 products to approximately 60 countries worldwide. The leader of Newcastle City Council, Councillor Nick Forbes, has expressed his support for this development.

Three senior officials of the local authority are leaving their positions. Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is departing on Friday at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. The opposition SNP group leader, Stephen Flynn, expressed concern about the council's ability to retain senior staff and anticipated further departures. The council chief executive, Angela Scott, acknowledged the dedication and professionalism of the departing officials.

Guy Martin has faced challenges in road racing this year, including a crash at the TT and mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he has no plans to race on Hondas for the rest of the year. Martin's decision comes after a disappointing experience at the TT, where he felt like a test rider and did not enjoy the event. He will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix and is interested in racing classics and unusual vehicles in the future.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) has won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP also lost the presidential poll last month for the first time, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP's decline was further highlighted by the results from the elections for governors and state assemblies, with the party losing control of key northern states and Adamawa, one of the three states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, and the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive. Elections were not held in seven states. The APC's victory is a historic gain, relegating the PDP to a regional party. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall, they have been more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes that Nigeria's democracy is maturing. The PDP will need to go through a period of introspection and rebuild itself under a new leader.

The passage discusses allegations made by a US-based environmental lobby group, Mighty, against the agricultural commodities trader, Olam, and its stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses both companies of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices, which may contribute to the haze in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia caused by fires used to clear vegetation for palm oil plantations. Olam confirms buying 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and says it has a strict sourcing policy. Mighty claims that Olam has created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and that Temasek's investment in Olam could link Singapore's state fund to the haze. Both Olam and Temasek reject the allegations, stating their support for no-burn policies. The palm oil industry is often accused of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and burning of plantations. The report also highlights concerns about Olam's operations in Gabon, where it is accused of bulldozing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam responds that its plans for developing sustainable palm oil plantations in Gabon are responsible and transparent.

The passage discusses a restaurant that began serving "puppy platters" after a new law was passed allowing dogs to eat at restaurants in outdoor areas. The passage includes an image of a dog's meal, described as a "dog's dinner." The new law was introduced on 27 August 2016.

Fernando Forestieri, a forward, has been dealing with a knee injury and may not be able to start in the upcoming game, having been limited to a bench role in the last two matches. Derby County's striker, David Nugent, has a chance to return to the lineup after missing the previous game due to a groin injury. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who recently scored a late equalizer against Huddersfield, is also hoping for a starting position in the next match.

The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) has lifted a ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 due to the uploading of the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." Google has provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of offending material within Pakistan, but YouTube has stated that it will only restrict access after a thorough review and that government requests for content removal will not be automatically granted. Some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms agreed upon between Google and the government. The lifting of the ban has been welcomed by many young Pakistanis. (Passage summary)

The head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, Domenico Scala, is being asked to withdraw from the committee due to sharing nationality with one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. This is based on a rule that states any member of the committee who has a conflict of interest must withdraw. Scala and another member, Claudio Sulser, had previously withdrawn from the committee for the same reason ahead of the 2015 elections. However, a spokesman for Scala argues that there is no conflict of interest in this case as there is no incumbent president and five candidates from different nationalities. The Liberian Football Association (LFA) chief Musa Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Bility had previously been denied participation in the elections himself and has pledged his vote to Prince Ali. The election is set to take place in 18 days in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) were killed in an explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, where they were working in a paint-spraying area. The incident occurred shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. A forensic search has been conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. The explosion is believed to have been caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and some sort of ignition, resulting in a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with the help of inspectors and electrical safety experts.

The passage discusses the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations and the controversies surrounding Tunisia and Morocco's participation. Tunisia was facing expulsion until they apologized to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints made during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco, on the other hand, was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on their participation. The ban was imposed after Morocco refused to host the 2015 Nations Cup, citing fears over the Ebola virus. The North Africans requested a postponement, but their request was denied. The tournament was eventually hosted by Equatorial Guinea. The passage also mentions a controversial penalty awarded to Equatorial Guinea in their quarter-final match against Tunisia, which led to a row between Tunisia and Caf. The Tunisian Football Federation insisted that they never accused Caf or the referee of corruption, but they did question the referee's appointment. The passage concludes with the draw results for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

The passage describes a mass altercation that occurred in a soccer match between Manchester City and Chelsea during the 95th minute of the game. The incident resulted in Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for violent conduct and Fernandinho serving a three-match ban. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola has apologized for his team's part in the incident. Both clubs have been charged for failing to control their players and have until 18:00 GMT on December 8 to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley and Neath in Wales, UK, focusing on patients suspected of having cancer by their general practitioners but not showing any urgent signs or symptoms. This initiative comes after doctors visited Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that patients in Wales without clear symptoms are waiting too long for a diagnosis, as they do not easily fit into specific treatment pathways. This results in general practitioners referring patients back and forth for multiple tests, which can take several weeks. The fear is that too many patients start treatment when their cancer has already progressed or is incurable.

The new scheme will allow 40 general practitioners in the Cynon Valley to refer patients they suspect may have cancer to a diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant within seven days. It is estimated that six patients per week will be seen and undergo various tests, ideally on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with symptoms that cause concern receive a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors aim to reach the majority of patients without such obvious symptoms earlier. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board. These trials have been developed over the past 12 months since specialists from Wales returned from Aarhus. Denmark established diagnostic centers due to concerns that the country was lagging behind in cancer survival rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network, believes the scheme will reassure patients and speed up the diagnostic process. If the pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley, which will last for six months, is successful, the remaining health boards in the area will offer the same service in the following months.

The hosts, England, won the match against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, making it their second biggest win in terms of runs. England's Joe Root, who was promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match for his exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches in Pakistan's first innings and claimed a wicket in his only over. England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, stating that it was as good an innings as he has seen. Pakistan's spirit was broken, according to former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott, as they batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered the bowlers little assistance. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq admitted that the team is short of confidence and that shot selection really cost them.

The passage discusses the British and Irish Lions being led by head coach Warren Gatland in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Wales' forwards coach, McBryde, will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, as the 2017 summer tour provides a unique opportunity for coaches to develop in different environments.

The passage describes a football match between Hull City and Southampton. Hull City won the match 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. The match was marked by early injuries to Hull City's starting strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, but substitute Robert Snodgrass scored a goal and provided an assist to help his team secure the victory. The win was Hull City's first in the league since 20 August, but they remain in the bottom three. Southampton's Charlie Austin scored the opening goal from a penalty, but the team was unable to maintain their lead and conceded two goals in quick succession in the second half. Despite pushing for an equalizer, Southampton was unable to break down Hull City's defense, with goalkeeper David Marshall making several crucial saves. The match was also marked by a remarkable goalline clearance from Hull City's Sam Clucas in the final minute of added time.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, around 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist was a local resident, but further details have not been released by the police. The tractor driver was not injured. The police are seeking witnesses to the incident and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

The President of Macedonia, Ivanov, cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This decision was criticized by the opposition and EU officials. The crisis began with the release of the recordings in 2015, which allegedly show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. The opposition leader, Zaev, has been releasing these recordings since February 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and revealing corruption. The government denies these accusations and has accused Zaev of trying to destabilize the nation. The move by President Ivanov was seen as not aligning with the rule of law by EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, putting Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk.

The passage discusses the current situation of the Swansea football club, which has recently sacked its manager Bob Bradley and is looking to appoint a new one, with Paul Clement being the top choice. The club is in a difficult position, facing the possibility of relegation, which could make it challenging to return to the Premier League due to the increasing strength of the Championship. The club's former player and current staff member, Curtis, believes that the club has lost its way since the departure of manager Michael Laudrup in 2014 and has not adequately replaced several key players. Despite the current challenges, Curtis believes that the team has the potential to stay up in the Premier League and reminds new signings of the club's history and the importance of their role in its continued success.

The Dagenham & Redbridge football team, managed by John Still, have been relegated to the National League after a loss to Leyton Orient. The team, which had previously reached League One in 2010, needed a win to keep their survival hopes alive. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet's winner sealed their fate. The team has struggled in both attack and defense this season, with a goal difference of -20 compared to the same point last season. Still, who returned to the club for his third spell in December, has committed to helping the team gain promotion from the National League next season. The loss comes as Leyton Orient interim manager Andy Hessenthaler's first win, keeping their play-off hopes alive.

Steven Gerrard, a former Liverpool captain, will return to the club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp had a long discussion with Gerrard about the role. Gerrard has expressed his desire to become a manager in the future and Klopp believes he has a bright future in this field. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left the club in 2015 to join LA Galaxy, winning several major trophies during his time at Anfield. He retired as a player in November 2016 and is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.

The passage describes a soccer match in which McManus and Johnstone score two goals each for their team, Morton, and Forbes and McAusland score one each for the opposing team, Alloa. The match ended with a comfortable win for Morton.

The UK's Office for Standards in Education, Children's Services and Skills (Ofsted) has found evidence of children being taught in poor conditions in three unregistered schools in Birmingham, which have now been closed. These schools were operating illegally, as any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week must be registered as a school. Ofsted's Chief Inspector, Sir Michael Wilshaw, has expressed concern that children in these schools may be at risk of abuse or radicalisation. The government is taking steps to address this issue, including providing funding for a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools and considering further regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. The education secretary has also stated that she intends to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools identified by Ofsted. The government's consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

The passage describes the establishment of Lilliard Gin distillery at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, which is part of a larger initiative to open the first whisky distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. The lead distiller, Kate Macinnes, expresses her excitement about the potential to make the region a hub for distilling excellence. Lilliard Gin is produced on a small scale, using local botanicals to capture the unique flavors of the Teviot valley. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery located on the same site, and both share a commitment to local sourcing and production.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell. Green, who was more than two times the legal driving limit, had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. The incident was prosecuted under health and safety legislation as it occurred on private land. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. The victim's mother, Pam Whitlam, stated that her close-knit family had been "changed forever" by the incident. The Health and Safety Executive described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green's behavior as "reckless".

The passage discusses the recent decision by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) regarding the ban imposed on Uruguayan footballer Luis Suarez following his bite on Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. While the initial ban prevented him from all football-related activities, the CAS has now allowed him to train and play in friendly matches. However, he still has to serve the remaining eight games of his record nine-match ban in competitive international games. The CAS decision is seen as a partial victory for Suarez, as it allows him to maintain his fitness levels and prepare for his competitive debut with his new club, Barcelona. The exact reasons for the CAS decision will be published at a later date. The ban was initially imposed by FIFA, and Suarez's lawyers argued that it was too strong a punishment. The world players' union, Fifpro, expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not strongly diminished, viewing them as disproportionate. Suarez's legal team considered the appeal a success, arguing that FIFA had misapplied its own rules. The passage also mentions Suarez's previous incidents of biting and a suspension for racially abusing another player.

The passage describes the victory of Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna in a wife-carrying race on 18th March 2014. They beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved a 380-meter course with obstacles like haystacks and a steep slope. The winners put in a week's worth of training and will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July. The race is open to all combinations of competitors, not just married couples.

The paper system for car tax discs will be replaced by an electronic system in October, which will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. This change may result in a reduction of job roles related to the tax disc and refund processing at the DVLA. However, the minister, Stephen Hammond, has assured that any reductions will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business. Mike Hedges, Swansea East AM, has welcomed these assurances and believes that the minister's response will provide comfort to concerned DVLA employees.

The European Union (EU) has expressed concerns over Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and a higher education law. The EU objects to these laws and has urged Hungary to withdraw them. However, the Hungarian Foreign Minister, Peter Szijjarto, has stated that the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" and that Hungary will not backtrack on these laws. The education law in question could lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros. Poland has reportedly pledged to veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. Hungary has also been accused of forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, raising questions about its compatibility with EU law. Additionally, draft legislation on NGOs is expected to go before parliament soon, which human rights groups say would stigmatize them as "foreign-backed" organizations.

The passage announces that Emma Watson, Dan Stevens, and Luke Evans will star in the upcoming live-action film "Beauty and the Beast," to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play the villainous Gaston. Other cast members include Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle's father, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper transformed into a teapot. Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou, and Bill Condon will direct the movie, which will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a well-known journalist and author, passed away after being diagnosed with cancer. He had been receiving chemotherapy and had dictated his columns due to dyslexia. Gill had been with the Sunday Times since 1993 and was praised for his writing style and compassion. Despite controversial articles, he remained a popular figure in journalism. He was married to Amber Rudd and later to Nicola Formby, with whom he had four children. Gill's final column will be published in the Sunday Times.

The passage describes an incident where Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, also known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator. The attack was said to have involved a bottle and repeated kicks to the face. The Russian embassy is investigating, but has called local press reports "distorted". The rapper was wearing a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika emblem during the performance. The swastika is a traditional symbol in Mongolia, not associated with Nazism. The rapper's father stated that his son was seriously injured and spent time in a coma. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified. The musician's lawyer, father, and a band member denied reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. The case is under investigation by the police.

12 campaigners from the group Plane Stupid were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome after staging a protest on the northern runway of Heathrow Airport on Monday at 03:30 BST. The demonstration was in opposition to the airport's expansion plans. The protesters will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police stated that security at the airport will be reviewed.

The passage describes a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire. Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, which was the highlight of their total. However, Gloucestershire's bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets, causing Glamorgan to struggle. Gloucestershire's innings was also challenging due to the conditions. The day ended with the match evenly balanced. Glamorgan is being led by Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck problem. Selman expressed his relief at getting some runs after a string of low scores, while Taylor was pleased with his performance for Gloucestershire.

33-year-old Craig Hughes from Flint was arrested by North Wales Police after making threats to shoot police officers in the Dee Estuary following a false report to the police. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. The threats were made while Hughes was drunk and he has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. The Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, which offers confidential support and counselling, reported the threats.

8-2, Surrey's score was boosted to 255-7 by a 130-run partnership between Davies (90) and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase was hampered by Meaker's 3-wicket burst, including Bairstow and Ballance. Despite Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Surrey's Davies and Foakes' partnership was crucial, with Yorkshire ruing dropped catches. The target was reachable, but Yorkshire's top five failed to make significant contributions.

The passage describes an incident where a 56ft converted trawler encountered a water ingress problem 6 miles west of South Stack. The crew contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST, reporting that their pump was insufficient to handle the incoming water. Holyhead coastguards responded, and the RNLI lifeboat crew provided a pump to help remove the water while towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will not be able to participate with the Scotland team at the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. The World Indoor Championships in March are a potential target for her, but her focus will be on her studies until her exams in May. Muir is optimistic about her future in running, stating she has at least two, possibly three more Olympics in her.

The passage discusses Liverpool's current struggles in the Premier League, focusing on their upcoming match against Chelsea. The author, Robbie Savage, attributes Liverpool's decline to a combination of overachieving last season, poor transfer decisions, and a lack of goals and intensity in their play. The defense remains a concern, and the team's set-piece proficiency has also dropped. Savage suggests a possible lineup for the Chelsea match and emphasizes the importance of Steven Gerrard's leadership despite his recent slip-up against Chelsea. The author also touches upon Gerrard's future with the club and the physical and mental challenges he faces in extending his career.

The passage discusses the plan to build a £45m educational facility in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council is seeking permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the renowned writer, William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, an English teacher turned full-time writer, is known for his novels, poetry, journalism, and broadcasting. He is also recognized as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" and has written acclaimed works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. The council aims to honor McIlvanney's legacy, as he was passionate about providing quality education for young people.

The area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated due to a sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s found in the river. Residents close by were advised to stay indoors, and an exclusion zone was set up on the river. The evacuation affected three streets, and wider safety advice was given to residents within 500m of the device. Ferry services were disrupted due to an exclusion zone at sea. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community. The mine was moved to a safer place for further handling due to its deteriorated state. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation.

The passage discusses the allocation of funding for various sports by UK Sport for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics. Cycling, despite bringing in 12 medals in Rio, had its funding cut by over £4m. Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, had its funding completely removed, a decision that Badminton England's chief executive described as "incomprehensible". Judo, which also won a bronze medal, had its funding slightly increased. Sports such as basketball, handball, and volleyball, which had their funding cut in previous years, criticized UK Sport for not investing in team sports. UK Sport has set a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Tokyo 2020, a £2m decrease from the record £347m allocated for the Rio Games. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, with £9m still to be allocated.

3 Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth will be demolished for a 6-storey, 4-star hotel and 2 assisted-living apartment blocks. The site includes Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The development is opposed by English Heritage and some residents due to its scale and impact on the conservation area. However, the planning board voted 7-3 in favor, stating it will benefit tourism and improve living for older people. The site will also include 90 hotel rooms and 122 assisted-living apartments.

The passage describes the trial of Jake Vallely and Aaeron Evans for the manslaughter of Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment. The attack occurred in Brecon while Pte Boyd was off-duty and on a night out. Vallely, who was cleared of manslaughter, punched and beat Pte Boyd, leaving him unconscious. The court heard that Vallely was on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. Evans was not present during the attack and was cleared of any involvement. Pte Boyd, originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was in Brecon for training exercises and was described as an "all-rounder" with a "promising career ahead of him." The family's tribute expressed their pain and loss, stating that Vallely's actions had created "a void in our family that will never be filled."

The chief executive of Barnet Council, Andrew Travers, left the authority by "mutual agreement" after an error occurred on election day where voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched. On election day, staff at one station said just three of the first 30 voters to show up were on the register. The rest were told to come back later. Barnet Council apologised for the problems and later offered emergency proxy votes to residents who had been affected. A review will conclude by the end of May and the findings will be presented publicly.

The passage describes a soccer match between Gateshead and Wrexham. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick for Gateshead, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with a set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's performance in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance. The match ended with a score of 2-1 in favor of Gateshead.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60. Norway ranks as the best country for the elderly, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank as the worst.

The passage describes a project by Airbus and OneWeb to create a network of at least 600 satellites, with the potential for over 2,000, to provide global broadband connectivity, particularly aiming to connect every school. The project requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing, focusing on high volume and low cost. Airbus and OneWeb have established an assembly line in Toulouse, France, with plans for two more in Florida. The first 10 satellites are set to launch in April 2023, with over 800 expected to be in orbit by the mid-2020s. The project faces challenges in obtaining necessary financing and dealing with potential space debris. The UK Space Agency is involved as the project has a company registration in the Channel Islands. The project aims to set new standards in debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit old spacecraft within two years. The new manufacturing approaches could potentially disrupt the satellite industry.

The UK government's recent spending review has put significant pressure on public spending in Scotland, according to Mr Swinney. The Scottish government argues that the cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010, along with the recent spending review, will result in a 12.5% reduction in its discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. Mr Swinney stated that 4.2% of this reduction will occur between now and 2019-20. The UK government, however, claims that the Scottish government will have £390m more in spending available to them next year. Mr Swinney has promised to protect schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland from these cuts. The Scottish government's priorities include maintaining more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition-free university education, and a record-level health budget. The UK government's Scotland Office has urged the Scottish government to focus on preparing for new powers and getting the best for Scotland, rather than focusing on grievances. Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, has called on the Scottish government to offer a real alternative to austerity and make different decisions on tax compared to the Tories and the SNP.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families when trying to find suitable toilet facilities in public places. Standard accessible toilets may not be sufficient for those who need assistance from multiple carers or a hoist to transfer onto a bench. The campaign for Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced facilities, is highlighted. These toilets are recommended for larger buildings but are not yet compulsory. The emotional impact on families and the need for more inclusive facilities are also discussed. The passage also mentions the positive experiences of some businesses, like Arsenal Football Club, that have installed Changing Places toilets.

The European Commission has received a formal complaint from Italian consumer organizations against McDonald's, accusing the company of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, including the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the UK. The complaint alleges that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to longer-than-average contracts and are forced to lease premises from McDonald's at above market rates. This is claimed to lead to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores. McDonald's stated that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and is committed to supporting them. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are founded. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

The #prayforjosh social media campaign, which began on Facebook and Instagram, is in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign was started by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff, and has since gone viral, with people from all over the world showing their support. A large billboard with the hashtag was recently erected at Holywood playing fields by a mystery donor, and there has been an outpouring of support on Twitter for the Bangor Grammar pupil. The campaign has been seen by over 79,000 people and has been shared 948 times.

The passage discusses the planned closure of Brecon Barracks, a military base in Wales with a long history dating back to 1805. The announcement was met with criticism from local Conservative MP Chris Davies, who vowed to fight the decision. Davies highlighted the barracks' historical significance, with soldiers from the site having fought in every conflict since the early 19th century, including the Battle of Rorke's Drift against the Zulus. The closure is part of a larger reorganization of UK military buildings, which will also see the closure of Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. However, the nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are not expected to be affected. The reorganization will also see the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. The closure of military bases is expected to impact the livelihoods of many people, causing "gnawing uncertainty" over their future.

The House of Lords has released a report discussing the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The industry, which makes up only 0.5% of the UK's GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, is at risk of being marginalized in the Brexit negotiations. The report highlights that the UK's commercial fish stocks are in shared waters with other EU coastal states, and that the UK exports most of its fish to the EU while importing a significant portion of the fish consumed by British consumers from the EU. The report also notes that the UK will need to continue to co-operate with neighboring states on fisheries management, even after leaving the EU. The report suggests that the UK may need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal, and that the UK will need to continue to base total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. The report also raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland after Brexit. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities that Brexit may bring.

The passage discusses the revelation of Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, as the source of leaks about US surveillance programs. Snowden revealed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to a vast amount of individual data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The US government confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon. The NSA's Prism program also reportedly enabled access to the servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple, although these companies have denied involvement. The extent of government surveillance has raised concerns about privacy and data protection, with different countries having different laws regarding data protection. The US Patriot Act of 2001 gave American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US. The UK, EU, and other governments have expressed concern and are seeking more details from the US authorities. Snowden said he acted due to concerns about privacy, stating that he does not want to live in a society that does these sorts of things.

The passage discusses the creation of OpenAI, a research organization backed by several high-profile tech figures and companies, including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The organization aims to conduct research on artificial intelligence (AI) with a focus on positive human impact, unconstrained by financial obligations. The passage also mentions concerns about the potential risks of AI, with figures like Musk and Stephen Hawking warning about its potential threat to humanity. However, OpenAI's goal is to ensure that AI benefits society and is an extension of individual human wills, distributed as broadly and evenly as possible. The organization plans to spend only a small fraction of the $1 billion pledged in the next few years.

Ben Parkinson, a soldier who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch for nearly half an hour with an assistant supporting his arm. Despite his brain injury, he has regained his speech and spends much of his time in the gym, rehab, and raising money for military charities. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. His mother has stated that the responses have been "phenomenal" and that Ben is "buoyed up" by the support. A total of 8,000 people will carry the Olympic flame during its 8,000 mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London on 27 July.

15% of Americans were living in poverty in 2011, with a total of 46.2 million people affected. This rate remained unchanged after three years of increases. The median household income decreased by 1.5% in real terms. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans without health insurance slightly decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, moved from Somerset to Lancashire in 2013 and has now signed a new deal with the team until 2019. He is a specialist in short-format cricket and holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan in 2015. Ashley Giles, Lancashire's cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and his contribution to the team's T20 Blast victory last year. Buttler has also been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians and is expected to return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates, HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, are currently in Portsmouth Harbour. The government's Disposal Services Authority is handling the sale, with a deadline for bidders to register interest set on 23rd January. No proposals for preserving the ships have been submitted yet, and the final decision is expected in spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt expressed interest in preserving at least one ship from the scrapyard, suggesting a reef and diving attraction. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with various weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities. The aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m last year.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced political instability and international isolation due to racial tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. Multiple coups have occurred, including one in 1987 that overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition, and another in 2000 where the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister was held hostage. These events negatively impacted the economy, particularly tourism, and led to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, prompting the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing between the two groups. The economy is diverse, relying on sugar, tourism, mining, services, and light manufacturing, but has been hampered by trade and budget deficits.

The passage discusses the current situation regarding Syria's chemical weapons and the recent attacks on a shipment of weapons. Syria has missed a deadline to destroy its entire stockpile of chemical weapons, and Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad has stated that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia. The US has expressed concern about the slow progress of the destruction of the weapons, with only 4% of the stockpile having been removed so far. The Syrian government has denied reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, and has accused the US of supporting "terrorist elements" in the country. The Syrian government insists that it is doing its best to comply with the timetable for the destruction of its chemical weapons, and that it is committed to all its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The passage discusses the 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, which includes six authors: Neel Mukherjee, Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. Mukherjee's novel, The Lives of Others, is the favorite to win, with a focus on a family in 1960s Calcutta. Jacobson, a previous winner, is shortlisted for his love story J. Smith's How To Be Both tells two interlinking stories, one about a renaissance artist and the other about a child of the 1960s. Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour explores atheism through a New York dentist. Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is a love story narrated by a college student. Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North is a love story set against the construction of the Thailand-Burma Death Railway in World War Two. Fowler's book is the best-selling of the shortlisted novels. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night.

The passage discusses a celebrity, referred to as PJS, who is appealing against a court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction preventing the publication of the celebrity's identity remains in place until the end of the hearing. The celebrity, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is seeking to prevent the Sun on Sunday from publishing an account of his alleged extra-marital activities. The Court of Appeal had previously ruled in his favor, preventing him from being identified in publications in England and Wales. However, the ban was lifted after the story was published in the US, Scotland, and elsewhere, and spread across the internet and on Twitter. The judges ruled that the details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost."

Fosse Park, a shopping center near junction 21 of the M1, was bought in August for £345.5m. The new owners plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, has discussed these plans with the new owners. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, stated that they aim to address parking and congestion issues, as well as improve the common areas and facilities to enhance the overall quality of Fosse Park.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast was initially held for review in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the film. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit and a "P13 parental guidance classification." The film's release date in Malaysia is yet to be announced. The "gay moment" involves LeFou, the sidekick of the film's main antagonist Gaston, who has feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film in Malaysia has been met with criticism from netizens.

The passage discusses the issue of unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in Southampton, where landlords are required to apply for a licence if they let properties to more than three unrelated people. The licence can cost up to £1,000, but the fine for not having one can be as high as £20,000. It is estimated that there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. The charity Shelter reports that tenants of HMOs frequently raise concerns about fear of eviction and poorly maintained properties. The mandatory licensing for HMOs in Southampton affects properties in certain designated areas and the council has so far prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not having a licence.

The passage discusses the efforts of Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil is open to facilitating a minority government but will not support a program for government. One of the main issues preventing an agreement is the future of water charges. Fine Gael sees a role for them, while Fianna Fáil wants to see their immediate removal. A commission to consider the future of national water utility Irish Water is one of the proposals being considered. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party was able to form a majority government, and TDs have failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, was traveling to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of the car decks, causing the evacuation of all passengers. The fire's cause is unclear. Three people were injured, one seriously, and were airlifted to a hospital. Other ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue. The passengers were taken to lifeboats and then to one of the ferries, the Puglia. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire. The rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive at the port in a few hours' time. Psychologists were being sent to the port to provide counseling. The distress signals were sent out at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs identified individuals, including students, who allegedly voted twice in the 2017 general election, which is a criminal offense. The commission suggested improving the coordination between individual electoral registers managed by councils to better identify duplicate entries. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registration applications, particularly in areas with large student populations. However, concerns persist over duplicate applications due to the lack of direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The commission proposed clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to address this issue. Labour warned against making it harder for young people and students to register to vote, as some may need to be registered in two places for reasons of work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star football player for the University of Nebraska and several NFL teams, was found dead in his prison cell on Wednesday at the age of 40, believed to have taken his own life. Phillips had a history of legal issues, including convictions for assault and the killing of his former cellmate, Damion Soward, 37. He was serving a term of over 30 years and was awaiting trial for Soward's death at the time of his own death. His former coach at Nebraska, Tom Osborne, described Phillips as an intelligent person with good qualities, but said he struggled with anger issues and was unable to overcome the difficulties in his life.

The passage describes the promotion of Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier, to the rank of lance corporal in the Mercian Regiment, a recognition for his good behavior. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to 1858, when the first Private Derby was acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot. Lance Corporal Derby XXX, who has his own army number and gets paid for his rations, joined the regiment in 2014. He has participated in various events, including switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling. During the mating season, he takes his holidays on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire.

The passage describes a thrilling 4-3 victory by Liverpool over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, a match that will be remembered as one of the greatest dramas at Anfield. The game was marked by an incredible comeback from Liverpool, who were down 2-0 within the first nine minutes, but managed to turn the game around with three goals in the last 33 minutes. The victory was a testament to the team's spirit and belief, as well as the passionate support of their fans. The win moved Liverpool closer to earning a place in the Champions League, and was seen as a significant moment in Jurgen Klopp's tenure as manager. The passage also highlights Klopp's impact on the team, his connection with the fans, and his belief in the team's ability to overcome adversity.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK government minister David Davis and Scottish government minister Mike Russell discussed the UK's plans for negotiating with the EU following the Brexit referendum. Davis expressed a desire to keep the devolved administrations informed about the negotiations and proposed monthly meetings to share information. Russell, however, expressed concern that the UK government had not made its strategic intentions clear and emphasized the importance of maintaining access to the EU single market for Scotland's economic prosperity. The Scottish government also plans to oppose the UK government in a legal challenge to the triggering of Article 50.

The passage describes a study of a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four that are identical twin sisters of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. The study, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, aims to determine the health and aging process of cloned animals. The sheep are subjected to various tests, including physical examinations and full-body scans, to assess their health and the presence of any age-related diseases such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could have significant implications for the future of cloning, are to be published soon. The cloned sheep, approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, currently appear healthy.

The passage primarily discusses the recent performance of the horse Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by jockey Frankie Dettori. Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes at York, beating runner-up Vintage Folly. Despite the soft ground, which was a concern for Gosden, Shutter Speed managed to win, leading to her being considered a top contender for the French Oaks at Chantilly. Gosden has decided to focus on the French Oaks rather than the Epsom Oaks, where his other horses, Enable and Coronet, are top contenders. The passage also mentions Tasleet's win in the Duke of York Stakes and the potential participation of Gosden's colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes, depending on the ground conditions.

The passage discusses the fluctuation of the British pound against other currencies, particularly the US dollar and the euro, in the context of the upcoming EU referendum. The pound initially slipped but then started to recover, only to fall again. This volatility is attributed to the uncertainty surrounding the referendum outcome, as recent polls suggest a tight race between the Leave and Remain campaigns. The volatility index, a measure of investor uncertainty, has reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argues that the pound's retreat is only to March levels. The passage also mentions the impact of this uncertainty on global stock markets, with Asian markets experiencing significant falls and the FTSE 100 in London also ending the day down. The reaction of hedge funds and traders to this uncertainty is also discussed.

The Iron, currently in sixth place in the National League, are one point and one position below the play-off spots after a recent loss to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Despite the loss, manager Cowley remains positive, highlighting the team's remarkable performance so far, even though they are a part-time team facing their toughest challenge yet. The team's losing streak has now extended to three games, but Cowley encourages the team to embrace and enjoy the challenge.

The passage discusses the shift of planning decision-making power from the Planning Service to local councils in Northern Ireland, set to take place in April 2015. This move will allow councils to accept or reject developments in their own areas, with the potential to positively impact community and development plans. However, concerns have been raised about the fairness and transparency of this system, given the history of discrimination in housing allocation and close relationships between developers and political parties. Friends of the Earth argue for the importance of transparency in political donations to ensure proper democratic planning. The Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to reveal more information about political donations.

The passage describes an incident where a one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun in NiddryView, Winchburgh, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, discovered the injured animal and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The Scottish SPCA's Chief Superintendent Mike Flynn expressed concern about the incident and advocated for the licensing of air weapons to prevent similar incidents. A consultation on licensing air weapons was previously held by the Scottish government, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA is seeking information about the incident.

The passage discusses the transfer of Christian Benteke from Aston Villa to Liverpool for a fee of £32.5 million, making him Liverpool's second most expensive signing. Benteke, a Belgian international, signed a long-term contract with the club. He had previously scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa. Liverpool's manager, Brendan Rodgers, hopes that Benteke's addition will help revive the team's attack, which struggled last season following the departure of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge both believe that Benteke will be a successful signing for Liverpool.

The passage discusses a study on the use of tablet devices in schools, which found that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets to some extent, with 9% of schools having a device for every pupil. The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found that while there is no clear evidence of academic improvement, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets can help motivate disengaged pupils. The research also found that a quarter of secondary pupils with individual tablets described themselves as internet "addicts" and two-thirds took a device to bed. The study predicts an increase in the number of tablet computers in schools from about 430,000 in 2014 to almost 900,000 by 2016.

The passage describes the "Growing Up in the City" exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool, which features 25 photographs of children's lives in Liverpool spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images capture various aspects of childhood, including play, special occasions, and even child labor. The exhibition is curated by Kay Jones, who selected the photographs from the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition aims to showcase both the positive and negative experiences of childhood, providing a social history of life in Liverpool through the decades. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

The passage discusses the transfer of two football players, Anderson and Keating, to the National League. Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their rivals, and could play against his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams and his move is subject to international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to be contracted to work with parental authorization, and sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law aims to reflect the needs of Bolivia, one of South America's poorest countries, and to help eradicate extreme poverty. Over 500,000 children already work to supplement family income in Bolivia, according to Unicef. The law has been criticized by the International Labour Organisation (ILO), which says children under 15 should not be allowed to work, but allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is studying the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress and TV host, experienced symptoms of a heart attack, including sudden nausea and aches, and discovered she had a blocked artery after looking up her symptoms online. She underwent a procedure to insert a stent into the artery. O'Donnell did not call emergency services and instead visited a cardiologist the next day. She shared her experience in a poem on her blog, titled "my heart attack," and warned women to be aware of heart attack symptoms and to seek medical attention.

16-year-old Che Labastide-Wellington was fatally stabbed at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, following a scuffle with a group of youths in an alleyway around 00:30 GMT. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Che was not involved in an earlier altercation with the group, but appeared to have been targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and three boys aged 14, 15, and 16 have been arrested in connection with the incident.

The passage describes a new approach to diagnosing cancer cases in Denmark, particularly those that are not initially obvious. The changes were implemented after Denmark's poor performance in cancer survival rates compared to other European countries. The new model of care has three routes: fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have led to better organization of patient diagnosis within existing resources and improved survival rates. The Danish health service has also set up strict time targets for patient investigation and treatment. The new system has helped break down barriers between GPs and specialists, allowing them to work better together to achieve a diagnosis. The lessons learned from the Danish system could potentially be applied to Wales, which has a similar health system in terms of funding and organization.

The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) is being replaced by Powys, who will be responsible for issuing warnings and banning orders against estate agents who act dishonestly or breach estate agent laws. This decision follows the UK government's disbandment of the OFT. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to carry out this work. People with complaints about estate agents should still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary. However, cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team and hopes this new role will demonstrate Powys's ability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The passage discusses a plan by NHS Employers to expand the roles of nurses and other healthcare staff to cover for doctor shortages and meet the changing needs of patient care. The Nuffield Trust, which reviewed the plan, found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The report highlights the need for more training and investment to enable healthcare staff to take on additional responsibilities. However, unions have warned against using this as a quick fix for the NHS's problems and emphasized the importance of proper training and funding.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed by Avon and Somerset Police following a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, and investigations are under way to determine the cause of the collision. First, the bus company affected, has resumed some services but warned it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. The company thanked the public for their support and understanding, and commended staff for their efforts during the situation and recovery.

The passage discusses a dispute between Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) and Natural Resources Wales (NRW) over the estimated impact of a planned lagoon on fish mortality rates. NRW estimated that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year, but TLP disputed these figures, claiming they had no clear scientific basis. TLP's own computer modeling estimated a worst-case scenario of the lagoon killing 2% of all species of fish. The dispute centers around NRW's methodology for calculating the figures, which TLP claims was not shared with them. NRW maintains that their figures are based on the best available evidence and that they have shared their methodology with TLP. The lagoon project is seen as a test bed for larger and more cost-effective versions around the coast, and its viability is currently under review by the UK government.

The passage discusses the announcement of a new agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland by the Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster. The body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities in the agri-food industry, which is a significant sector with nearly 100,000 jobs. The Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill also welcomed the move, stating that it will help in delivering export-led economic growth for the region. However, she noted that the plans could have implications for the work of other organizations, including her department, and looked forward to discussing the plans with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. This is part of a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees in tribute to the millions who died during WW1, with the goal of creating four new woods across the UK. In Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted to honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The public is invited to participate in the planting, and the trust will provide saplings. Volunteers are advised to wear appropriate footwear. The project aims to create a space for wildlife and a place for people to walk, relax, and reflect.

The Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award was won by Hilary for her book "Someone Else's Skin", a thriller that deals with domestic violence and honor crime, and is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The book was praised for its fine writing and tight plotting. The shortlist for the award was strong, and the other books on the shortlist were not named. Sara Paretsky, the creator of detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career writing about the character. VI Warshawski was a game changer, being a strong female protagonist who was also an action hero. Paretsky also set up Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers around the world. The awards were handed out at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival.

The passage discusses the return of Mitch Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, to Worcestershire County Cricket Club as their overseas player for the 2017 season. Santner, who is 24 years old, had previously played for the club in 2016 but suffered a finger injury in only his second game. The director of cricket, Steve Rhodes, expressed that Santner's injury was a significant setback to their hopes of qualifying. Santner is set to rejoin the team after the ICC Trophy in England in June 2017. He expressed his excitement to return and make an impact with both bat and ball. The passage also mentions that Worcestershire had previously signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 by a speeding car on a dual carriageway in Kiev. The car had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. The coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger than him and they met online in 2006. She was not present at the scene of the accident, as she had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. Ziuzina tried to claim Pring's assets within days of his death. Pring's family believe he was killed in a staged hit and run accident. The Ukrainian police closed an inquiry into his death, but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

The passage is about a boy named Charlie from Merseyside, UK, who needs to return to Seattle, USA for experimental T-Cell Therapy, as the previous transplant failed and there are no further treatment options available in the UK. The treatment is being funded by an anonymous donor, who specifically asked to pay for Charlie's treatment. The family, who were previously left "heartbroken" and concerned about funding, are now "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by the donor's generosity. The treatment will start as soon as possible, with the date to be confirmed next week.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system for its iCloud service to enhance security and prevent unauthorized access to users' intimate photos. The system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device in addition to their username and password when logging in from a new device. This security measure was previously available but did not apply to the backup service. The change comes after reports of third-party software, such as Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, being used to steal celebrities' private photos from iCloud. The new system is an opt-in choice, and users are advised to keep a 14-character recovery key to regain access to their accounts in case of loss or theft of their trusted device. Despite the improvements, there are concerns about the recovery key being lost or stolen, and some experts suggest that Apple should make two-factor authentication the default option instead of recommending it.

The passage discusses a potential deal where Ian Wright, a former non-league football player, may buy 20% of Billericay Town FC, a club currently in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Dan Groves, a club representative, stated that the details of the deal are not yet finalized. There are rumors that Wright might become a club director. The club was recently taken over by Glenn Tamplin, a millionaire who is investing significantly in the club. They have also signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

The passage is about Sports Direct owner, Mr Ashley, being asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers at the company's warehouse in Derbyshire. The request was made by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, after a BBC investigation into the company's working practices. Mr Ashley was invited to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook, but he has not yet agreed to attend. The committee has given him until 21 March to respond and has warned that if he fails to agree to attend, they may seek the support of the House of Commons in respect of any complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has previously pledged to review worker rights, with oversight by Mr Ashley.
