The passage discusses a report, "Putin. War," which was started by murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and later completed by his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin. The report accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, using Russian soldiers and equipment to secure victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report presents evidence of volunteer soldiers admitting to being directed by Russian generals and receiving significant salaries. It also estimates Russian spending on the conflict to be around 53bn roubles. The report was created after Nemtsov heard that relatives of dead Russian soldiers had not been given promised compensation. However, the relatives never went public, and after Nemtsov's assassination, they became even more scared. The opposition plans to seek donations to extend the initial print run of the report, but publishing and distributing it is difficult due to fear and lack of support. The report is seen as unlikely to have a significant impact on public opinion, as many Russians already accept their country's involvement in eastern Ukraine.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered with fatal head injuries at the Woodhead Tunnels on Monday at 11:00 BST. He was 34 years old and from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham. A post-mortem confirmed his death was due to head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman have been arrested in Sheffield in connection with the incident and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the issue of the UK government not sharing the Article 50 letter with the Welsh government before publishing it, which Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, finds unacceptable. The letter outlines the UK's plan to leave the EU and its desire for free trade within the single market. Alun Cairns, the Welsh Secretary, defends the UK government's actions, stating that they have been discussing the letter's contents for months. The passage also mentions that the UK government plans to consult on which powers should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland after Brexit, but the specific powers in question are not identified.

The passage describes an incident in which two cars were damaged in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on a Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his disapproval of the "mindless attacks" on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI were reportedly "carrying out duties" when the attacks occurred, and they have appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

The passage discusses the legal dispute between American Apparel and its co-founder and former CEO, Mr. Charney. Mr. Charney was removed from the company due to employee complaints, accusations of misuse of company funds, and inappropriate behavior, including illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts. Mr. Charney filed a defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair, but the company's court filing presents evidence of his misconduct. The board stated that they do not expect Mr. Charney to return to the company due to the risk he poses to the company and its shareholders. A restraining order was granted to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company and from trying to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Britain and Greece at the Copper Box in London. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website. Greece won their previous encounter 92-64, but three key players from that team will be missing in this game. The match is significant for Britain as it is their only home game before they compete in the FIBA EuroBasket 2017. The team's coach is Joe Prunty. After the game against Greece, Britain will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as part of their preparation for EuroBasket. The game will start at 17:30 BST.

The passage describes the launch of the iPhone in 2007 and its subsequent impact on society. The author initially struggled to obtain the device for a news piece but was eventually able to do so. The iPhone's release was met with skepticism, with some viewing it as just another product launch. However, the author compares its significance to that of the Model T Ford, suggesting it would revolutionize the way people live. In the decade since its release, the iPhone has become a transformative technology, putting powerful computers in the hands of billions and disrupting various industries. The author notes that the iPhone changed the way people thought about photography and other activities, making them more accessible on the go. Despite initial skepticism, the author expresses gratitude for having witnessed the launch of the iPhone, recognizing it as a pivotal moment in history.

The passage describes a series of cat poisonings in Victor Avenue, Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, where all the cats have ingested antifreeze. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday after consuming the toxic substance, and three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, with another cat dying two weeks ago. The RSPCA is investigating and appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely. The poisonings are unclear whether they are accidental or deliberate.

The passage discusses the current political and economic situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is set to implement more austerity measures mandated by creditors. Despite these measures, which have been previously criticized by Syriza, there is a lack of public protests. The passage suggests that this may be due to the public's anticipation of the details of the new bailout agreement, which is expected to be revealed later in the week. The agreement is expected to include painful VAT increases, pension cuts, reductions in farm subsidies, and controversial privatisations. The passage also notes that despite the economic hardships, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular. However, the continued closure of banks and lack of credit is expected to further harm the economy. The passage concludes by suggesting that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors will need to ease Greece's debt burden and avoid triumphalism in the face of Greece's capitulation.

The passage discusses the return of actor Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in the soap opera EastEnders, for a brief appearance. He is returning for the final episodes of Barbara Windsor, who plays his on-screen mother, Peggy Mitchell. Her character is set to die from cancer in the spring. Kemp's character, Grant, was last seen in 2006 and was involved in many dramatic storylines, including an affair with his brother Phil's wife. The return of Grant Mitchell is described as a reunion of the Mitchell brothers and a chance for them to say goodbye to their mother.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was convicted of the murder of Alice Ruggles in October following a stalking incident. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed of her death by Northumbria Police. They had previously contacted the police about Dhillon's behavior, but were reassured that it would be alright. Alice's mother, Dr. Hills, expressed guilt over her response to Alice's concerns about Dhillon. The family has set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon, 26, was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison for the murder.

The French firm EDF has approved the funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, but the UK government has announced a further review of the project, causing a delay in the signing of contracts. The project, which is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement, has been met with concerns about EDF's financial capacity and environmental damage. The Chinese investors are providing one third of the total cost. The government's decision to review the project comes after EDF's board voted to approve the project and is seen as a potential change in policy. Critics of the plan have warned of environmental damage and potential escalating costs, while supporters argue that it is necessary for the UK's energy supplies and climate commitments. The project has been in the works since 2006 and has faced several delays and uncertainties.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person your spouse committed adultery with, but there is no obligation to name them. Family lawyers express concern that naming the third party can increase conflict and complexity, and may lead to delays and increased costs. The form has been updated to make the legal process more user-friendly, but lawyers worry that people may not read the guidance which states it is not normally necessary to name the person your spouse committed adultery with. In 2015, there were just over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales, with adultery being the reason for 12,148 of them. The Ministry of Justice states that it has always been possible to name the person believed to have been involved in the adultery, but it is not required.

The passage discusses the conflict between the environmental and commercial aspects of forestry in Wales. Conifer forests, which have been a significant part of the Welsh landscape for decades, are important for the timber industry. However, there has been a decline in commercial forests, with at least 16,000 hectares lost since 2001. This is concerning as Britain is the world's third largest importer of wood, and the timber industry in Wales is estimated to be worth over £450m per year. The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development. However, the current system is seen as too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas, and there is a perceived emphasis on environmental aspects over commercial forestry. Despite a high demand for timber, only 90 hectares were planted last year, far below the long-term targets set by ministers.
A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, around 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with a serious condition.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys by Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. The Arctic Convoys were a series of missions during World War II where vessels traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. The convoys faced constant threat from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe weather conditions. More than 3,000 men died during the campaign. The Russian Embassy sought to award the Medal of Ushakov to survivors in 2012, but the move was initially blocked by the Foreign Office. However, the British Government later allowed an exception to the rules, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals in London in 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found issues with the implementation of unpaid work sentences for offenders, including delays in starting the work and a lack of consequences for non-attendance. The report, which looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, found that some offenders had completed very little of their required hours. The report made 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the frequency of offenders being turned away and creating objectives for unpaid work that match the offender's circumstances. The Ministry of Justice has said it is acting on the report's recommendations and wants to ensure more effective rehabilitation, including consequences for offenders who do not turn up on time.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding comedian Russell Brand, who advocates for economic and political revolution to help the poor, yet lives in a luxury home. Brand was confronted about his living situation while supporting a campaign for housing rights in London. The Sun newspaper accused him of hypocrisy, a charge that has been made against him before. Brand has responded to these accusations in the past, acknowledging his wealth and fame but emphasizing the need for systemic change and sharing wealth. He also points out that his personal choices do not detract from the issue of economic disparity.

The passage describes the life and scientific achievements of J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, who is known for his work in human genomics and the creation of a synthetic life form, Synthia. Venter's unconventional approach to science, which often involved private funding and competition with public projects, led to significant advancements in the field, but also brought him criticism from the scientific community. His work on decoding genes and the human genome, as well as his efforts to create synthetic life, have been met with both controversy and recognition. Venter's motivation for his work is attributed to his experiences during the Vietnam War, which instilled in him a sense of urgency and a determination to become a doctor. Despite the criticism, Venter's contributions to the field of genomics and synthetic biology have been significant, and he has been involved in various projects, including the exploration of marine microbes and their genomes.

80% of children in England who eat school lunches have tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home. Parents of 628 children who eat school lunches reported that their children asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among these children are carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach are among the least popular. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after a survey by Mumsnet suggested some parents give their children packed lunches because they think their children are too fussy to eat anything else. School meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines, and about four in 10 primary school children in England eat school lunches. The survey was conducted online among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish footballer, is currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He previously played for Juventus for two years, scoring 27 goals and winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, where he had played for four seasons and scored 10 goals. Real Madrid has an option to buy him back for a fee of up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata, who is 6ft 3in tall, has been a target for Arsenal and Chelsea and has scored three goals for Spain in France. He also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, returned to the Championship team Forest in August 2013 from Celtic for £2.5m. He was released in May and has since been without a team. He had previously spent four seasons with Forest and also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant, Tesco, has agreed to sell its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to the Los Angeles based private equity firm, Yucaipa. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will provide a loan of around £80m to the new business. Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores, has been losing money since its opening in 2007. Tesco will incur a cost of £150m to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, but part of that is a loan which may be paid back. If Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. This move comes after Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April.

The passage describes how a martial artist, after facing racial abuse, considered representing France but ultimately decided to continue targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a special guide for getting into martial arts.

The passage provides an analysis of the changes in the size of glaciers in the French Alps over the past few decades. The research, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, indicates a significant retreat of glaciers in the region. The new French Alps glaciers inventory, produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues, assessed roughly 600 glaciers in various massifs, including the famous Mont Blanc Massif. The team found that the overall area of ice in the French Alps has decreased from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s, representing an average loss of some 26% over the last 40 years. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors. However, the northern region, which includes the biggest French glacier of all - La Mer de Glace, has seen a smaller decrease in size. The research mirrors findings of retreat occurring in other sectors of the Alps.

The Scottish women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for a major tournament, having won all five of their qualifiers so far. They are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, and a win would virtually secure their spot in the tournament. The team has previously suffered losses in the play-offs for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup, and forward Lisa Evans has expressed her desire to avoid another heartbreak. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland at number 20 in the world, is also unbeaten in their qualifiers. The outcome of the upcoming match and the return fixture in Reykjavik is likely to determine who tops the group. Scotland is currently in a strong position to qualify automatically for next summer's finals in the Netherlands, as the best six of the eight group runners-up will also qualify. The team is aware of the challenge posed by Iceland, but they are confident in their ability to win. The squad includes 12 players who play outside of Scotland, with five in English clubs, four in Sweden, and two in the United States National Women's Soccer League. Evans, who recently celebrated winning the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern Munich, believes that having more players in the world's top leagues benefits the national team. The Scottish women's league is improving, but playing abroad provides a different culture and way of playing, which adds to the national team.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish blogger and campaigner for Scottish independence, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London. She alleged that he had harassed her over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, stated that the allegations concerned some tweets, which he insisted were not threatening. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the matter. Campbell accused the media of encouraging speculations and innuendo. He has been a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011.

PETA has proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a fish, called "A Happy Plaice," to promote a more animal-friendly image. PETA argues that the current mascot represents cruelty to animals in the fishing industry. However, the mayor of Skegness is open to suggestions but believes there is little support for replacing the beloved mascot, which has been associated with the town since 1908. The proposal will be considered by the council.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland led the game with a try by Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, and scores from Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, and Hamish Watson. Georgia's Vasil Lobzhanidze scored two tries for the visitors. The match was characterized by Scotland's dominance in possession and territory, and Georgia's strong scrum. Scotland's Greig Laidlaw contributed with successful conversions and a penalty. The final score was 43-16 in favor of Scotland.

The passage describes a rugby match between Widnes and Castleford. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime with tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Bridge, and a response from Cas loanee Paddy Flynn. Flynn scored again in the second half, but Widnes extended their lead with tries from Ah Van, White, and Mellor. Despite a late comeback from Castleford with tries from Patrick, Gale, and Flynn, Widnes held on to win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth. The match was officiated by referee J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti national, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel determined he was not a significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denied. The release was in line with a US Supreme Court challenge. al-Odah is the first inmate to be released since May 2014 and faces a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. The total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay is now 148.

The passage describes the commemoration of Anzac Day, which honors the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, particularly the Gallipoli landings. Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Services were also held at Westminster Abbey, with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital was in 1916, and it has since become an important moment for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war, and the allied operation was an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

30-year-old striker, Clarkson, has joined St Mirren for a second spell in the Premiership. He previously played for the team in July and could make his debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. Clarkson scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has mostly been used as a substitute this term. He has been keeping fit by playing for the U20s and is looking forward to getting started at St Mirren. The team is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa. Clarkson has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level and has been capped twice for Scotland, scoring one international goal. He has previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was acquired by food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were initial concerns about the future of the existing workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements will be honored. The final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and members now have an alternative pension scheme, which will not be affected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office, Mr. Boparan's private investment, stated that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews will continue under the new ownership. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to a highly profitable business through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing the present spare capacity to process chicken, not just turkeys.

The new vessel at Cowes has experienced several problems since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. The council has ordered a review of the project and has made the crossing free until 2 July to allow for feedback and in recognition of the problems. Some local businesses have reported loss of trade due to the issues with the ferry, and the council is considering compensation. The council has also authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report discussing the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The report highlights that the industry, which only contributes 0.5% to the UK's GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, may be a low priority for the government in the wider Brexit negotiations. However, it emphasizes that the industry must not be marginalized. The report also points out that the majority of UK fish are exported, mainly to the EU, while a significant proportion of the fish that British consumers eat is imported, often from EU states. This means that continued market access is crucial for the success of the industry. The report also notes that many elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) should be retained post-Brexit, and that the UK will continue to be under international obligations to co-operate with neighbouring states. The report also raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland once the UK leaves the EU. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry still believe that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

The passage describes how Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, was found guilty of taking or permitting the creation of indecent images of children between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, put on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a sex offender program. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing determined that his actions were fundamentally incompatible with being a registered teacher and removed him from the professional register. The panel found that his conduct was likely to recur due to the volume of images and duration of the behavior, and prohibited him from applying to re-register for two years.

The passage discusses a fire that occurred on 2 March at a site run by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited in Duncan Street, which led to disruptions in train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste after the fire. The fire service had visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months and found the site operators to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, meaning the company can no longer operate from the site and must remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The Syrian government is working to destroy its chemical weapons stockpile, but has missed a deadline to hand over all of it. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia. The US has criticized the Syrian government for its use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, but the Syrian government denies targeting civilians and insists it is defending against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government also denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison. Russia has said that Syria should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by March 1st. The Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, has stated that Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations to destroy its chemical weapons.

The passage describes the second Test match between England and Pakistan, in which England won by a significant margin, leveling the series. England made a high score in their first innings, with Joe Root scoring 254, and declared their second innings at 173-1. Pakistan was bowled out for 198 in their first innings and 234 in their second. Root was named man of the match for his performance. The passage also mentions that Pakistan's spirit was broken and that they will need to work hard to come back in the series. Former England players and coaches praised England's performance, particularly Root's. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, acknowledged that his team needs to work on their confidence and shot selection.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is seeking to gather evidence from older people, their friends, and families about their experiences in residential care. This information will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies, as part of Ms. Rochira's review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. The review aims to assess whether older people living in residential care have a good quality of life, considering factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. However, Care Forum Wales has expressed disappointment that the main advisory panel does not include a provider expert, which they believe misses an opportunity for partnership working.

The passage announces that Paul Sheerin, former Dons midfielder and player-manager at the Red Lichties since 2010, has been appointed as the new manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. The change comes after Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two following a last-place finish in League One during the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser mentioned that manager Derek McInnes conducted a comprehensive process before choosing Sheerin. Despite Arbroath's desire to keep Sheerin, chairman John Christison understood Sheerin's wish to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin, who has played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s and led Arbroath to their first national trophy in history, the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

The passage discusses the recent sacking of Bob Bradley as the manager of Swansea City football club and the appointment of Curtis and Paul Williams as interim managers. The club is looking to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with Paul Clement being the top choice. The text also highlights the challenges of getting promoted back to the Premier League if the team is relegated, and the loss of the 'Swansea Way' since the departure of Michael Laudrup in 2014. The club's remarkable rise from near bankruptcy a decade ago to the Premier League in 2011 is also mentioned, and the importance of staying in the league for the club and the local area.

The passage describes the life and work of biologist and entrepreneur Dr. J Craig Venter, who is known for his contributions to the field of human genomics. He was involved in a competitive race to map the human genome, which led to the publication of the human genome in 2001. After this, he turned his attention to creating a synthetic life form, which resulted in the creation of an organism called Synthia. Dr. Venter's work has been met with criticism and controversy, but he has also been praised for his innovative approaches and the potential benefits of his work, such as the creation of synthetic microbes that could help reduce dependence on oil and reverse environmental damage. Dr. Venter's sense of urgency and determination to make scientific breakthroughs stem from his experiences as a medic in the Vietnam War.

The Sutton Trust has warned that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, with only 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting each year rated at level three (equivalent to A-level). The report, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, found that just one in five (20%) employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to over half (51%) in Germany. The report also notes that England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330. The report calls for the expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, the majority of which should be at level three or above, and for no more than 10% to be two-year courses at level two. The Department for Education says apprenticeships are being reformed to "drive up standards".

Sarah Storey, a British cyclist, won her 16th world title in the women's C5 time trial event in Nottwil, Switzerland. She finished two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is aiming for more success at the 2020 Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro, has a total of 22 Paralympic medals, including 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze, in both cycling and swimming. She has won 21 world titles in both sports. Storey, who started her career in swimming, has won six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005. She will have a chance to win her 17th title in the road race on Saturday.

The passage discusses the financial troubles of Hereford United, a Conference Premier club, which led to their expulsion from the league. The club had a debt of £148,000 to their football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle and members of the current squad. Despite several deadline extensions, the club failed to meet the payment deadline, leading to their expulsion. The last team to face a similar fate was Chester City in 2010, who were later reformed as Chester FC. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had made an offer to buy the club for £1 and clear their debts, but it was not the preferred option. The club's financial troubles began after their relegation from the Football League in May 2012, with average attendance dropping significantly. Former Hereford manager Foyle, now at Southport, signed two players from that same Bulls team, keeper Dan Lloyd-Weston and Kingsley James, who both left the club due to unpaid wages.

The passage discusses the retirement of English footballer James Milner from international duty. Milner, who made his senior debut in 2009, has 61 caps for England and was part of two World Cups and two European Championships squads. However, he only played for three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. The decision to retire from international duty is described as being about "common sense."

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He was known for his significant contributions to the early-music movement and worked with many leading orchestras around the world. Hogwood directed the AAM for approximately 30 years, during which they made over 200 CDs, including a famous recording of Handel's Messiah. He was also a musicologist, keyboard player, and held various academic positions at institutions like Harvard University and the University of Cambridge. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date.

The passage describes a boy from Northern Ireland who has been unable to attend school due to a lack of available places in special schools. His parents had to remove him from mainstream schooling as he was not coping, and they are still waiting for a place at a special school. The family was told that all special schools in the area were full, and no time frame was given for when a place might become available. The boy's mother is concerned about the impact of this situation on her son and other families, as the special needs school system is at capacity. The Education Authority is reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland but could not comment on individual cases.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, with the intention of making Rodney Parade a rugby venue. Newport County, who are fellow tenants with a lease until 2023, have primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. Newport County chairman Gavin Foxall stated that they expect their contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be voted on May 9th. In 2013, Newport County agreed to a 10-year lease to use the stadium after promotion to the Football League. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. On the pitch, Newport County are fighting to avoid relegation from League Two, with relegation being a significant blow for the team and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the experiences of a former child soldier in Sierra Leone, who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) at the age of 15 and forced to commit violent acts. After escaping and serving time in jail, he was rehabilitated by a preacher named Richard Cole and went on to help fight the Ebola epidemic in Sierra Leone in 2014. The speaker and his team educated people about Ebola, provided food and support to those in need, and set up an Ebola treatment clinic. The passage also notes that the country was recently declared free of the virus, which had killed almost 4,000 people in the country over the past 18 months.

80,000 pieces of art, ceramics, and other items from the Wedgwood Museum in Staffordshire, which were at risk of being sold to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, have been saved from auction. A public fundraising campaign reached its target in just one month, allowing the collection to remain on display at the museum. The collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and then loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale was finalized by administrators on Monday, following complex negotiations. The collection was at risk of being sold after the museum inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill when the firm collapsed in 2009, and then went into administration itself in 2010. A high court judge ruled in 2011 that the collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. The collection is considered important for Staffordshire and Britain's cultural development.

The passage discusses a potential deal where 30-year-old footballer, Ian Wright, may buy 20% of Billericay Football Club. The details of the deal are yet to be finalized. Wright, a former non-league football player and runner-up of I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, could become a club director. Billericay, currently under the ownership of multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, is eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

The Seasiders (Blackpool) scored first in a match against Colchester United with a goal from Jamille Matt in the 12th minute. Colchester equalized shortly after through a Kurtis Guthrie goal. Despite numerous chances, including a missed opportunity by Tom Aldred for Blackpool, the game ended in a 1-1 draw. Colchester's Sean Murray was sent off in injury time for a dangerous tackle on Jim McAlister.

The Fawley power station, an oil-fired power station commissioned in 1971, is set to be transformed into a glass structure, which will be the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The 198-meter-high chimney will be the centerpiece of a Â£1bn development, which includes a merchant city, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, which was capable of powering one million homes, was closed in 2013 and the site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016. The development is expected to start in 2018, following the application for outline planning permission later this year.

The passage describes the events at the Hong Kong cycling championships. Mark Cavendish's son, Casper, won a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's silver medal in the women's scratch. GB's men's team pursuit finished in fifth place, failing to secure a medal. Joe Truman, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, was outclassed in his semi-final, and in the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman and six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's performance. Elinor Barker, who joined the team pursuit quartet, remained positive about their progress despite not medaling. Katy Marchant, Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

The passage discusses the return of actor Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in the soap opera EastEnders, for a brief appearance. He is returning for the final episodes of Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who is set to die from cancer. Kemp's character, Grant, is the son of Peggy Mitchell and the brother of Phil Mitchell, played by Steve McFadden. The return of Grant Mitchell is described as a reunion of the Mitchell family, and it is said to be an opportunity to show Kemp and McFadden at their very best. The return is also described as a chance for the Mitchell brothers to be reunited with their mother for the last time.

The passage discusses a soccer match between Liverpool and Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs), where Spurs lost 2-0 with Sadio Mane scoring two goals in quick succession. Spurs have struggled in away games, with only two wins since September, including defeats against top-six rivals. Manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed disappointment in the team's lack of desire to win and their inability to cope with pressure, which he believes makes it difficult for them to challenge for the Premier League title. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy also commented on Spurs' poor performance, suggesting they should have stuck with their usual formation and improve their away performance quickly.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP also lost the presidential poll last month for the first time, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP's decline was further highlighted by the results of the elections for governors and state assemblies, with the party losing control of key northern states and Adamawa, one of the three states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP won only 8 governorships, mostly in the south-east, with the result in Taraba still outstanding and the election in Imo state declared inconclusive. Elections were not held in seven states. The APC's gains have made the PDP a regional party, with most states in the north and Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, going to the APC. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, with 66 violent incidents reported by the Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec). The PDP will need to rebuild itself under a new leader, as it has been in power for 16 years and faced widespread allegations of corruption during its rule.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22, will offer an augmented reality app experience for visitors. This app will allow users to access online information from signs, posters, and other items on the festival site. The online material will include videos and band interviews. The lineup for this year's festival includes acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and get a sense of its atmosphere. The app's message will be updated leading up to and during the event, providing users with information, interviews, and the ability to purchase tickets.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for two Birmingham academies, Park View and Nansen Primary, due to inadequate ratings by Ofsted. The schools were part of the Park View Educational Trust, which may be removed from running the schools. Four schools, including Park View and Oldknow Academy, were warned about losing funding due to concerns. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools reported feeling undermined by parents during an Ofsted inspection. The Trojan Horse letter scandal involved an alleged plot to introduce hardline Muslim teaching in Birmingham schools. Ofsted inspected 21 schools and rated five of them inadequate, including Park View and Oldknow. The Department for Education criticized Park View for failing to promote spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils. The trust plans to challenge the Ofsted report and the termination of funding agreements. The passage also mentions similar issues with Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School.

The passage describes the case of Vincent Barker, who passed away in July 2012 following a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The eye specialist, Honey Rose, is accused of gross negligence manslaughter for allegedly failing to detect swollen optic discs during the test, which could have indicated a build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain. This failure to meet the expected standards of a competent optometrist is considered by the prosecution to be the cause of Vinnie's death, which they argue was preventable had Ms. Rose performed her job properly. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a man, Clive Weatherhogg, who was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with another man, and of sending sexual images to the woman's sister. The incidents occurred between September 2013 and September 2014. Weatherhogg was also found guilty of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner towards the woman's father. He was remanded in custody and the case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. The woman testified that she felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. The defense counsel stated that it had been a shock for Weatherhogg to be placed on remand. Weatherhogg, a first offender, was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

The passage describes a T20 cricket match between Ireland and Afghanistan. Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson, Gary Wilson, and William Porterfield contributing significant runs. However, Afghanistan chased down the target with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad's batting performances. The Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took two wickets. Ireland's captain, William Porterfield, expressed that they fell short of a big score and didn't execute their bowling as planned. Ireland also faced a setback with paceman Boyd Rankin's injury, who is expected to return for the one-day internationals.

The Spanish champions, Barcelona, paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of Neymar to the club, including the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and a recent tax payment, is £106.8m. Barcelona has made a supplementary tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover any potential interpretations of the contracts drawn up in the operation to sign Neymar. The club denies any tax-related crime in relation to the transfer. Neymar has scored 7 goals in 18 league appearances and 3 in 7 Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao on 15th September. The UK Metropolitan Police sent detectives to work with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery. The UK detectives have completed their work in Thailand and will now compile a report and update the victims' families. The UK Foreign Office had previously expressed concerns about the police investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. Post-mortem examinations found that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds.

The Scottish women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for a major tournament, having won all five of their qualifiers so far. They are set to face Iceland, who are also unbeaten, in a crucial match. A victory would all but secure their place in the finals. The team has previously suffered play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup, and forward Lisa Evans has expressed that missing out again would be devastating. The team is taking a step-by-step approach, focusing on one game at a time. The squad includes 12 players who play outside of Scotland, with several in top leagues around the world. Evans herself recently won the women's Bundesliga in her first season with Bayern Munich. The team believes that having more players in top leagues benefits the national team as they aim to qualify for their first major tournament.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access to user data, following the leak of celebrity photos. The system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device in addition to their username and password. This security measure, previously optional, now applies to iCloud back-ups, preventing third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker from accessing user data. Vladimir Katalov, the owner of Elcomsoft, acknowledges the security of Apple's new implementation. However, he raises concerns about the recovery key, which could be lost or stolen, potentially leading to data loss or unauthorized access. Professor Alan Woodward suggests that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all major tech companies, not just Apple. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage provides a summary of the campaign spending by various political parties in the UK for the European election. UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives at £2,980,815, the Liberal Democrats at £1,580,575, and Labour at £1,027,339. The Green Party spent £534,249. The SNP spent £267,372. The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending per vote was 68p, the Conservatives' was 79p, Labour's was 26p, the Liberal Democrats' was £1.45, and the Green Party's was 43p. All parties, except for Labour, spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

The passage discusses the transfer of two football players, Anderson and Keating, to a new, unnamed club. Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. The other player, Keating, is a 21-year-old striker who was recommended to the Gulls boss by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. His move is subject to international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but had never collapsed before and did not show these symptoms on the day of his death. He had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described as the "horse of a lifetime" by his trainer, Oliver Sherwood. Despite the rarity of such incidents, the British Horseracing Authority is determined to do more to understand what causes these symptoms and whether more can be done to prevent them.

The passage describes the emotional farewell speeches of Presiding officer Tricia Marwick, veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and former first minister Alex Salmond, who are all standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Salmond used his speech to reiterate his belief in Scotland's diversity and the need for greater responsibility in governance, while McNeil warned of the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster in terms of accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, is also leaving Holyrood and joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears by the speeches of both McNeil and Salmond.

The passage announces that Emma Watson, Dan Stevens, Luke Evans, and Josh Gad will star in the upcoming live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will play Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. Additionally, Kevin Kline has been cast as Maurice, and Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans died. The decisions are based on files of evidence related to 23 suspects, which were referred to the CPS in January. The cases involve investigations into the causes of the disaster and the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police in its aftermath. A private meeting will be held in Warrington where relatives of the victims will be informed of the decisions. Margaret Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed anticipation and mixed emotions, hoping for accountability for the tragedy.

The passage discusses recent incidents of packages being thrown over the wall at Chelmsford Prison. A local resident has witnessed this happening multiple times, and a former inmate claims that the prison is known for being flooded with contraband such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issue and states that staff are working hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons. They also mention that laws have been introduced to punish those who smuggle packages into prisons with up to two years in jail. There is no evidence of drones being used for smuggling at the Chelmsford site, contrary to the former inmate's claim.

The passage describes a court case involving Brian Wright, who is accused of causing serious injury by dangerous driving to Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady who was hit by his car outside Bedford Road Lower School. Wright admits to hitting Blackburn but denies the charge, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. The incident occurred when Blackburn was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road, and Wright's car failed to stop at a red light. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will not be able to participate with the Scotland team at the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies. She will be focusing on her exams in May and completing her final year of studies. Muir finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. She is considering participating in the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir set a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m race at the World Athletics Championships.

22-year-old Trevor Deely went missing in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search is currently underway in Chapelizod, Dublin, at a three-acre site near the River Liffey. The search is expected to last several weeks and will involve excavations. Earlier this year, a team of detectives reviewed Mr. Deely's case and released enhanced CCTV footage showing him talking to a man dressed in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. The man, who has not been identified, was also seen following Mr. Deely on Haddington Road. The police are renewing their appeal for this man to come forward.

The passage describes the recent victory of Argentine tennis player Juan Martin del Potro over Swiss player Stan Wawrinka in a Grand Slam tournament. Del Potro, who has been ranked as high as number four in the world but has struggled with injuries and is currently ranked 165th, won the match in four sets. The victory was particularly significant given del Potro's recent injury problems, which have caused him to miss more than two years of play and undergo three wrist operations. The passage also notes that del Potro is in the same half of the draw as Britain's Andy Murray and could potentially meet him in a later round. Additionally, the passage mentions that Australian player Nick Kyrgios also won his second-round match and could potentially meet Murray in the last 16.

The passage discusses the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations and the participation of Tunisia and Morocco. Tunisia was facing expulsion from the tournament for complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) but apologized, resolving the issue. Morocco, on the other hand, was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation. The ban was imposed after Morocco refused to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns. The passage also mentions a controversial penalty awarded to Equatorial Guinea in a 2015 quarter-final match against Tunisia, which led to a row between Tunisia and Caf. However, the issue has been resolved, and both teams will participate in the 2017 tournament. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will compete against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage discusses the current struggles of the McLaren Formula One team, which has a rich history of success with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. The team's decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and despite having the best engine at the time, they have since faced problems with their Honda power-unit. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998, and their last drivers' title was in 2008 with Lewis Hamilton. The team's history has been marked by cycles of triumph and decline, and the current predicament is seen as a part of this cycle. Despite the team's struggles, team principal Ron Dennis believes that success will return and that McLaren will be the next team to break Mercedes' dominance in F1. The team's belief in their ability to turn things around is seen as crucial to their future success.

The passage describes a court case involving a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on October 6, 2014. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were both charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The defense solicitor admitted that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to. The judge ordered the closure of the bar for three months and fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000. The judge also expressed concern that he did not have the power to impose a custodial sentence.

The passage describes a Golden State Warriors basketball game in which Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, with a total of 8 three-pointers in the game. The Warriors won the game 116-105 against the Portland Trail Blazers, with Curry scoring 45 points and Klay Thompson adding 26. The Trail Blazers' LaMarcus Aldridge and Damian Lillard scored 27 and 20 points respectively. In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and 15 rebounds, and Derrick Rose adding 12 points. The Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit, while the Heat were outscored 57-27 in the second half.

The passage describes an event where Liverpool footballers Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic met YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen at Melwood. The players were led to believe that van Velzen was a competition winner, but they soon realized he was a skilled free-kick taker. Van Velzen, who has gained fame by uploading free-kick videos on YouTube, impressed the Liverpool players with his skills. He also surprised Balotelli with a t-shirt featuring the player's infamous slogan from his Manchester City days.

The passage discusses a study indicating that women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by over 60% if they undergo an oophorectomy (ovary removal) after being diagnosed with breast cancer. The study, conducted in Canada, analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with the mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, of which 345 had an oophorectomy after their diagnosis. The results showed a significant decrease in breast cancer death in women with the BRCA1 mutation who had the procedure, but not in those with the BRCA2 mutation. The study also found a reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The procedure was performed an average of six years after breast cancer diagnosis, and the protective effect against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The authors suggest further research, particularly on carriers of the BRCA2 variant. Angelina Jolie, who carries the BRCA1 gene mutation, had a double mastectomy in 2013 and an oophorectomy in 2015.

The passage describes an incident where a married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina on Easter morning. The accident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property, and none of the 166 passengers on the train were injured. A man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing on its route. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp, according to a man who knew them. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next destination, and the trip from Charlotte to New York City usually takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

The passage describes the story of Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. Toro, once a mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, became one of DEA's most important assets, aiding in the prosecution of high-profile criminals like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, Toro faces deportation as his temporary visa expired, and the DEA has not helped him with his citizenship. Toro, now retired due to health issues, fears for his life if deported to Colombia. The DEA declined to help Toro with his citizenship, and he remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport.

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is looking to crack down on a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., that is using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge high fees from celebrities and companies to protect their reputations. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains. ICANN is investigating whether the company's actions are illegal and has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs. The company has been charging around $2,499 a year for these domains, while other domain names can be registered for just $1 a year. The advisory body representing major companies and industry groups has called this a 'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory.'

27 years after a baby boy's body was found in a Sainsbury's bag in a village pond, his mother was arrested. The boy's body was exhumed and a DNA sample led police to her. She explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. The body was reburied in the village churchyard and named Peter. The mother remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. No foul play is suspected.

The passage describes a case where a taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to his passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving taxi. The incident occurred in 2010 in Bath, Somerset, when Hicks was on his way home with his girlfriend. The driver mistakenly believed Hicks was not going to pay the fare and decided to take him back to the rank. Hicks, feeling threatened, jumped out of the moving vehicle and sustained severe injuries. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, and he is entitled to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50% of what the family had requested, which is thought to be 'hundreds of thousands of pounds'. The judgment also awarded Hicks an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Hicks, now 27, requires round-the-clock care from his mother due to the injuries sustained.

The passage discusses severe weather conditions in Kansas, Missouri, and other nearby states. Tornadoes were reported near Goddard, Kansas, and southwestern Kansas, as well as in Potosi, Missouri. Storms and potential tornadoes pose risks to other communities. The National Weather Service also indicated a tornado may have touched down in Potosi. The storms have caused wind damage, flooding, and hail. Severe weather is expected to continue in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

The passage describes the upcoming middleweight clash between Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive victory, aims to be the "bull" to Machida's "matador" style. He believes he has identified Machida's weaknesses and plans to dominate the fight. Machida, also confident, respects Rockhold but believes he can stop him with his own strategy and technique. The winner of this fight could potentially earn a title shot.

The passage describes an incident where an aeroplane, an Aerostar, landed on a runway in Fort Pierce, Florida without deploying its landing gear. The plane skidded along the runway, causing damage to its propellers. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off again. The incident was captured on video and the sound of the propellers hitting the runway is described as memorable. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale after the incident and landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error.

The passage discusses Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini's disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season. Manchester City is reportedly open to offers for Toure at the end of the season. Pellegrini, however, has vowed to support Toure until the end of the season. The article also mentions Manchester City's struggles this season, with goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledging the players' responsibility for the team's performance. In a related note, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned left-back Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to Manchester City, where they may not get enough playing time.

The passage describes the case of Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia member who was set to be extradited to Italy after being convicted in absentia for his role in the Cosa Nostra. However, his sentence was dropped as it had expired in October 2020, and his European arrest warrant is set to be withdrawn. Rancadore, who has lived in the UK for over 20 years, was given a seven-year sentence in 1999. Although his conviction remains, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still need to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, expressed confidence that the Italian government will withdraw their application for a European arrest warrant, allowing Rancadore to live in peace in England with his wife and family.

The passage discusses the upcoming Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, where Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, has been installed as one of the three co-favorites at 7-2 odds. The other co-favorites are Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. AP McCoy will have six rivals in the race, and Mr. Mole will be his last ride in a Grade One race. McCoy announced his intention to retire after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February. The other runners in the race include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

The passage describes the story of Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter, Marcia, was raped, choked to death, and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. However, 40 years later, Ritter decided to view the crime scene photos, expressing a desire for revenge. The photos showed Marcia's body with signs of violence, including a blackened mouth, swollen head, and signs of sexual assault. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years.

The passage is about professional golfer Rory McIlroy's desire to win the Masters tournament to complete his career grand slam. McIlroy, who is currently the world number one, believes that winning at Augusta National is a career-long goal for him. He has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, but he remains confident that he will win the tournament at some point. McIlroy's collapse in the final round of the 2011 Masters was a significant moment in his career, as he learned a lot from the experience and went on to win his first major title two months later. The passage also mentions McIlroy's personal life, including his decision to call off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki, and how he uses golf as a way to escape from the pressures of his personal life.

The passage is a summary of several trending stories from a particular week. The stories include the appearance of four rainbows in the New York area, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr.'s (RDJ) agitated response to a UK interviewer's questions about his private life, a new social media trend called the #kyliejennerchallenge which involves using a jar to plump lips to look like Kylie Jenner, a 102-year-old woman named Alice Barker watching footage of herself dancing in the 1930s and 1940s, a controversial prom-posal that referenced bombs, the casting of Ewan McGregor as Lumiere in the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, the release of the trailer for the movie Black Mass in which Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable, a woman announcing her pregnancy with a reference to The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, and a military dad photobombing his son.

The passage reveals that 272 children were hospitalized in England in the past year due to foetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb. However, the actual number of children affected by this syndrome could be much higher, with research suggesting that at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure. The passage also highlights the story of a 15-year-old girl, Niamh Brown, who was born with foetal alcohol syndrome and requires assistance with daily tasks. The article concludes by noting that while the government advises pregnant women to limit their alcohol consumption, some experts believe that abstinence is the best policy.

A man named Shaun Andrew McKerry, previously known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his frequent returns home after committing crimes, attempted to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham, on March 15. The 31-year-old, armed with an axe, was tackled by the store owner, Sab Dhillon, and hit by his wife, Sam, with a baseball bat. The couple managed to disarm and subdue McKerry until the police arrived and arrested him. McKerry had previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in prison. He has a history of criminal activity, including shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party at a Canadian barracks in Nova Scotia. The sailors, who were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team, are accused of sexually assaulting the victim, who is in her early 20s, after a hockey game on April 10. The sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, have been granted bail on the condition that they live at the nearby Stadacona naval base and continue to work for the Royal Navy. They are not allowed to leave Nova Scotia, apply for new passports, or contact the victim or six witnesses. The case is still under investigation and the results of forensic tests could lead to additional charges. The sailors are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

The passage describes the story of a mother, Valerie Jackson, whose four-year-old son, RJ Jackson, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide. The condition causes RJ's skin to appear red and scaly, often leading to misunderstandings and mistreatment. A stranger once reported Mrs. Jackson to the police for child abuse due to RJ's appearance. The family faces regular taunts and ignorance from the public, including being denied entry to play centers and facing cruel comments. Despite the challenges, Mrs. Jackson remains positive and focuses on caring for her son, regularly applying creams to ease his symptoms. The condition was diagnosed when RJ was a baby, and there is no cure, but symptoms may improve with time.

The passage discusses the removal of Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" advertisements from the London Underground. The ads, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked controversy and backlash from feminists and body image campaigners due to their perceived promotion of an unhealthy body image. A Change.org petition to remove the ads garnered over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints. The ads were removed after a three-week period, which was the duration Protein World had paid for. A protest against the ads was also planned. Protein World engaged in the controversy on social media, defending their campaign and responding to critics. The company claimed the image was unaltered and that they were a fitness brand promoting health and confidence. The Advertising Standards Authority was assessing complaints about the ad, and Protein World had received threats, including a bomb threat, due to the campaign.

The passage discusses planned fare hikes by rail firms, with some increases as high as 87%, despite promises from political leaders to freeze or cap prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western (FGW) to review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. The fare increases will affect passengers traveling from Charlbury, the Oxfordshire station nearest to his constituency home, who will see an 87% increase in the cost of an off-peak return to London. The planned changes have angered Mr. Cameron's constituents, prompting him to personally intervene. Other rail firms, such as London Midland and Virgin, are also implementing fare hikes, with some increases as high as 24.5%. The fare increases come despite promises from political leaders to freeze or cap prices, and have angered passengers who might have expected price freezes.

66-year-old former soldier John Young and his 54-year-old wife Elaine were in their Oldham home when their front window was pelted with stones by unknown individuals. When Mr. Young opened the front door to confront the attackers, he was struck in the face with a brick, causing an open wound to his forehead and a serious injury to his left eye, resulting in blindness in that eye. The incident occurred just three weeks after the couple's wedding. Police are investigating but have found no motive, suggesting it may have been a case of vandalism or "messing around" by the offenders. The couple is now too scared to return to their home.

25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, who missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident that resulted in his father's death, has signed a new one-year contract extension. Poynton, a former England under-19 international, underwent ankle surgery and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the 2015 season and has committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work in his recovery.

The passage describes the story of a five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with cancer in various parts of his body, including his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To help him through his radiotherapy treatment, Harley created a superhero mask, inspired by the Ninja Turtles. The mask not only made him feel stronger but also caught the attention of hospital staff, who allowed him to decorate the protective mask used during his treatment. After his story gained international attention, Harley received a box full of Ninja Turtle presents from the children's TV channel Nickelodeon for Christmas. Recently, doctors gave Harley's parents the incredible news that he is cancer-free, following a year of intensive treatment, which included chemotherapy, an operation to remove a kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. Harley's bravery and resilience have made him the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids & Teens campaign, aiming to raise funds for research into child cancers. Neuroblastoma is a rare and aggressive form of childhood cancer, affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, and it is the second most common solid tumor in childhood. The cause of neuroblastoma is unknown, and symptoms can vary depending on the location of the tumor. Treatment options for neuroblastoma include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old footballer for Aston Villa, is at the center of a decision between playing for the Republic of Ireland or England internationally. Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood wants Grealish to focus on his club career and continuing to establish himself in the first team. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees that his son should concentrate on his club football and that the international decision will come later. Grealish has played for the Republic of Ireland's youth teams but is also eligible to play for England.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at various airports for private jet travelers. The fees vary significantly, with some surprising airports, such as Salzburg, Austria, and Darwin, Australia, charging the highest fees. These fees provide insight into the popular transport hubs for the wealthy. The busiest times for private jet companies are during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix.
