The most expensive airports for landing fees are Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Japan, and Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Japan. The only US airport to make it into the top 10 is LaGuardia in New York. The UK's Bristol Airport is the only British airport featured in the top 10.

The passage describes a video of two dogs, Cooper and Daisy, at a McDonald's drive-thru. Cooper, a Labrador, quickly eats an ice cream cone in one bite, while Daisy eats slowly. The video has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers have criticized the dogs' owner, Katie Gallegos, for feeding them ice cream, but she insists it is fine. Cooper and Daisy have also been treated to a "pup-uccino" at Starbucks.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock Football Club after a successful interim period. He initially joined the club as an assistant manager to Allan Johnston in the summer of 2021. Following Johnston's departure in February, Locke took over as the interim manager and has since lost only one game in seven. The former Hearts boss has now signed a three-year deal with the club.

The passage describes a situation where a Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is accused by Seminole County Elementary School of potentially having her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, suspended due to his use of essential oils. The school claims the oils, produced by Doterra, are a distraction due to their smell. Kemp applies these oils to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Although the oils have been in use for a year, a teacher's aide recently complained. The school board sent a letter stating the oils were causing a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat of suspension, Kemp plans to continue using the oils, citing their positive impact on her son. The school district has stated they will not suspend Logan, considering it a health issue. The family uses oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

The passage describes a fire that destroyed a beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, consisting of 90 condos. The fire was so intense that it caused the building to collapse and melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire teams were unable to control the flames, and the building manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything. The cause of the fire is unknown but is being investigated, with claims that it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The complex is open between May and November and is used as a holiday home by residents. The fire could be seen from three miles away and produced smoke that poured over Westhampton Beach.

The Queen, at the age of 88, was seen enjoying a horseback ride in Windsor Great Park on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, accompanied by a groom on another pony. The Queen, known for her love of horses, has been riding since she was four years old and has owned several steeds over the years. Despite being encouraged to wear a riding helmet, she prefers to wear a silk scarf due to her hair. The Queen has reduced her riding time in recent years due to a knee injury but remains an enthusiastic equestrienne, breeding horses and ponies at her stables, including fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud. Fell ponies are one of the oldest equine breeds, originating from the moors of Cumbria, and are known for their docile nature and hardiness. The Queen's love for horses has been passed down to her grandchildren, who also ride her horses and ponies.

The passage describes an incident where a 55-year-old man, Leon Yeaman, was allegedly killed by a single punch from his 28-year-old neighbor, Phillip Pama, following a dispute over noise levels. Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was sleeping when Yeaman was making noise in his yard. After confronting Yeaman, Pama allegedly punched him, leading to his death. Pama's defense lawyer claimed that Yeaman was known for causing disturbances and that Pama hit him blindly while being pushed. Pama was granted bail with conditions and the case is set to return to court on May 18.

52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was caught on hidden camera ordering a hit on her 15-year-old former student and lover, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) to a friend to find someone to torture and kill Vanya. Russian police set up a sting operation, sending an undercover officer to pose as a hitman. Simonova was arrested after handing over expenses money to the undercover officer and has been charged with attempted murder. Vanya had ended the relationship with Simonova to be with a classmate.

The passage discusses Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho's personal life and beliefs. Mourinho prays every day and speaks with God, but never discusses football with him or his wife. He separates his professional and personal life, and only prays for things in his personal life. He is a family person, a good friend, and supports people he doesn't know. He has worked as an ambassador against hunger with the World Food Programme. Despite his competitive and emotional behavior in his professional life, he considers himself a good person. His son, Jose Mario, was present at Chelsea's Capital One Cup victory. Mourinho goes to church regularly only when he is in Portugal.

The passage discusses the return of Bob Barker, a long-time host of the TV game show "The Price is Right," after an eight-year absence. On the April 1 edition of the show, Barker, 91, hosted the initial price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over the duties to the current host, Drew Carey. Despite his absence, Barker appeared comfortable and familiar with the show.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house, resulting in felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The arrest occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE by the Metropolitan Police. The agency revoked Baldwin's security clearance and put him on leave. He is part of the Foreign Missions Branch, which deals with the United States' diplomatic activities. The arrest comes after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave due to misconduct allegations, which are being investigated by the police and the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. These incidents are the latest in a series of controversies for the agency responsible for protecting the President and his family.

The passage describes a freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, who took a significant risk to photograph a lion at close range in Lahore's safari park. Saeed left his car and approached the lion, lying on the ground to take a few photos. The lion, alerted by the camera's shutter sound, reacted aggressively, causing Saeed to quickly retreat to his car. Saeed expressed that he would not repeat this dangerous action again.

The passage describes the discovery of an unidentified woman's body in Brooklyn, New York. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 and had no identification on her. She had a distinctive tattoo of a heart with the name 'Monique' on her right leg. The police have released an image of the tattoo in hopes of identifying her and determining the cause of her death.

The passage describes a New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, who built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of an old flatbed truck. After returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009, they couldn't afford to buy property, so they constructed their own home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. The project took about a year and a half and cost them around $25,000. The home is mostly self-sufficient, with solar panels providing most of the electricity, a gas-powered stove and hot water, and water coming from a nearby spring. The interior is lined with aromatic cypress wood, and the exterior is surrounded by trees and a babbling brook. The couple plans to build another similar home in the future.

The passage reports on a study conducted by researcher Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University. The study found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class during an academic year performed significantly better in early literacy tests than those who did not use iPads or used them individually. The shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher in the test. The research suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology, not just the collaboration itself, contributed to the improved literacy scores. The findings will be presented at the 65th Annual Conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

The passage describes a piglet that has become an internet sensation due to its ability to walk on only its two front legs. The piglet was born without its back legs and has learned to balance on its front trotters. The video of the piglet has attracted many viewers and visitors to the farm in Qionglai city, Sichuan province, China where it lives. This is not the first time an animal with two legs has gained attention in China, as a rabbit in Liuzhou zoo has also become a popular attraction for its ability to hop on its front paws.

During the 2023 IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member named Todd Phillips, who works as a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone. Dracone had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25 and accidentally struck Phillips while exiting his pit box, clipping his leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center for a leg cut and has since been released. The race was marked by poor traction due to rain, and Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

The passage describes a horrific incident in which a husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally attacked and killed his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, also known as Amanda Bueno, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The attack was captured on CCTV and shows Severiano slamming his wife's head into concrete and shooting her in the face multiple times. He confessed to the crime, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. The couple had only been married for four days at the time of the incident. Severiano stole a neighbor's car to escape but was apprehended by police after crashing it. He was found to be in possession of several firearms and a bulletproof vest. The motive for the murder was Severiano's jealousy and suspicion of his wife's fidelity.

The passage is about journalist and author Sarah Wilson's personal struggle with mental illness, specifically anxiety, which led her to consider taking her own life. She felt increasingly isolated due to a combination of issues including stress, her thyroid disease, and distance from family. Wilson believes that anxiety and depression are closely linked and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression". According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. If you or someone you know needs help, contact Beyond Blue or Lifeline.

The passage describes an incident where a pregnant Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, attacked her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom. Curtin was initially charged with second-degree assault but was later cleared of the charge as she was deemed justified in her actions. The ex-girlfriend, who has a child with Curtin's boyfriend, had a history of harassing Curtin and attempting to lure her boyfriend back into drug use. The incident occurred in November 2014, and Curtin gave birth in January. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

The passage describes a video of a pit bull named Gemma being fed treats by her owner in California. The owner attempts to trick Gemma by including a broccoli spear among the treats. Upon consuming the broccoli, Gemma displays apparent disgust and subsequently spits it out. The passage suggests that Gemma's aversion to broccoli should not be emulated by the two children she lives with, implying that they should instead learn to enjoy eating greens. The text also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family when she is not eating.

The passage describes an incident where a link on HSBC's official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was originally intended for the bank's young entrepreneur awards page, which was scrapped in 2011. The registration for the page was allowed to retire, causing the URL to redirect to a pornographic site. HSBC has since removed the link and apologized for the inconvenience caused. The bank maintains that its website remains secure.

13-year-old Marcus from Maryland called 911 after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton. He and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus provided clear instructions to the dispatcher, helping firefighters enter the room and rescue them. Despite the situation, Marcus remained calm throughout the 11-minute call, even comforting his sister. Both siblings were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while three other family members who escaped on their own were taken to a different hospital.

The passage describes the appearance of blue fluorescent algae on Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, South Coast of NSW. The phenomenon was captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described it as a beautiful supernatural scene. The glow is caused by a single-celled phytoplankton called Noctiluca scintillans, which omits light as a defense mechanism. This algae blooms in the spring and autumn, and it is usually due to natural causes. A similar display was previously observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in 2014.

The passage discusses the development of new tests that can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors, which can help determine the aggressiveness of the cancer and the likelihood of its recurrence. These tests, such as Endopredict, can provide a score that indicates the risk level of cancer recurrence, with a low score suggesting that chemotherapy may not be necessary. This could potentially spare many breast cancer patients from the difficult side effects of chemotherapy. The tests are currently available privately and cost around £2,500, but there is hope that they may become available on the NHS in the future. The passage includes a quote from a breast cancer patient who was able to avoid chemotherapy due to a low score on the Endopredict test.

25+ women have been emergency airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past years, including at least one from HMS Illustrious. This information was revealed through a Freedom of Information request. The Royal Navy has a strict 'no touching' rule at sea, suggesting that these women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female. The Ministry of Defence confirmed the data, stating that there is a strict 'no touching' rule in place at sea.

The passage describes the discovery of a drone carrying traces of radioactive material on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing cesium, was found by a staff member. The amount of radioactive material is not immediately harmful to humans. The incident raises concerns about potential terrorism, particularly in light of the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit in Japan. The Japanese government is reviewing how to cope with the threat of terrorism from drones. The Prime Minister, Shinzo Abe, was not in his office at the time of the discovery, as he was in Indonesia for the Asian-African conference. The discovery coincided with a court approval for the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a move that is unpopular among many Japanese.

The passage describes the story of a security guard from China, Lu Xincai, who takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because he fears she may get lost if left alone at home due to her degenerative disease. The man's mother used to get lost when she went to the mountains to collect firewood, and after the father passed away, Lu Xincai became her primary caregiver. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off the bike. His employers, a bank, have given his mother a room to stay in while he is at work. Lu Xincai feels a duty to care for his mother, as she devoted her life to caring for her children.

The passage discusses a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, which found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012. This increase is largely due to rising rates among women, with binge drinking rates among women increasing more than seven times the rate among men nationwide over the course of the decade. The study also found that despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. The increases in women's drinking habits are attributed to changing social norms. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, with the highest rates of binge drinking found in Menominee, Wis., and the lowest in Madison County, Idaho. The cost of excessive drinking is estimated at more than $220 billion per year, with 8 percent of Americans considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent binge drinkers in 2012.

The passage discusses concerns raised by UN officials about the increasing rate of C-sections, which they believe should only be performed when medically necessary due to the risks and costs involved. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a rate of 10-15%, while the current rate in England is over 25%. The WHO warns that C-sections can lead to short- and long-term health problems, including infections and even death. The procedure is also more expensive than natural birth. The WHO's statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow women to have C-sections even without medical justification if they are anxious about childbirth or have had a previous complicated birth.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, has been arrested and charged with breaking and entering, larceny, and malicious destruction of property after she allegedly broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered her in the living room of his $800,000 summer home. Filkins was arrested on April 17 after attempting to re-enter the home. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins with items from the home, possibly having a yard sale or giving them away. Items missing include deck chairs, a grill, side tables, lamps, framed posters, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. Police are asking anyone who received these items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department. Filkins' next court date is May 14.

The passage describes how a lost iPhone was reunited with its owner, Bella Crooke, after police in Melbourne posted a series of humorous photos and messages on Bella's Facebook page. The phone was handed in to Albury police station, and officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page to alert her to its location. The police continued to post updates and respond to messages on Bella's Facebook page until she was able to retrieve her phone. Bella was grateful for the police's efforts and their sense of humor, and she has since put a password on her phone.

The passage describes a tragic incident where a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed during a fight between two adult hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The calf accidentally got caught in the fight and was thrown into the air, dragged along the water surface, and eventually killed despite its mother's attempts to protect it. The fight between the two adult males had been ongoing, and the mother hippo had initially chosen to stay with her herd, believing it to be safer. The incident was witnessed by a tour operator, Stacey Farrell, who was horrified by the event. The baby hippopotamus succumbed to its injuries and died hours later.

The passage describes a three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, being sold for £575,000, which is significantly lower than the average price for the area. The low price is due to the property having only three years left on its lease. The property is in need of renovation and is being sold "as is." The cost per year for the remaining lease would be around £191,000, or £15,000 per month, which is comparable to the average rent for a three-bedroom flat in the area. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson and has received significant interest despite the short lease. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and any buyer would need to negotiate a lease extension with them. The properties in the area were built in the late 19th century and have a rich history, with notable past residents.

The passage describes a computer outage that occurred at Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, causing registers to malfunction and prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The outage affected 7,000 stores in the US and 1,000 in Canada, and while the exact cause is not specified, it was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. The outage was resolved by Saturday, and stores were expected to open for business as usual. The glitch prevented the acceptance of credit cards and the ringing up of sales, but some stores still accepted cash. The outage led to excitement on social media, with customers sharing photos of their free drinks. However, some stores closed early to avoid giving away free products. The outage occurred a day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

The passage discusses the use of rural areas in West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, as training locations for terrorists. Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit revealed this information. The activities appear ordinary but have a hidden motive. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998, with instances like hate preacher Abu Hamza sending extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons and the 7/7 bombers visiting North Wales. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is believed to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences in Llanybydder. Community intelligence is crucial for authorities to address these issues.

The passage describes the discovery of an Omura's whale, a species previously thought to be extinct, on a beach in West Australia. The whale, a 5.68m juvenile female, was found after tropical cyclone Olwyn and was identified through DNA profiling. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The species is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and several unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses a female businesswoman in Texas, Cheryl Rios, who believes that Hillary Clinton should not be president because her hormones might make her irrational and lead to unnecessary wars. Rios argues that men and women are built differently and have different hormones, and that women should not be able to start wars. The passage also notes that throughout history, male hormones have impaired some male leaders' decision-making, and that studies show that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts. The passage also mentions that Rios has received criticism for her views, and that there is a bias against women in the workplace. The passage concludes by stating that equality benefits everyone, and that it is important to say to our daughters that they can be anything they want to be, despite what some people might think.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is selling his collection of over 200 antiques, estimated to be worth £100,000, at an auction. The collection includes a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. Hardy, a keen military historian and a student of J.R.R. Tolkien, has also published two books on the history of the longbow and was consulted as an expert during the raising of the Mary Rose. The auction will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. Michael failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered dead. He is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. The murder weapon has been found, but the cause of death has not been publicly disclosed. Michael was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) has awarded the city of Eugene, United States, the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the IAAF council, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a "unique strategic opportunity" to bring the event to the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated that the decision to award the 2021 event to Eugene is in the interest of the global development of athletics. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

The passage describes the conviction of Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger, along with her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and his friend Nicholas Chandler, lured Hassan to his death in a plot to steal his winnings. The trio was found guilty of robbing and killing Hassan, with Jackson and Chandler receiving life sentences with a minimum term of 36 years, and Granger receiving 16 years for manslaughter. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by Judge William Kennedy. Granger, who had worked with the elderly since she was 18, became involved in the plot due to her love for Jackson and was found to be deceitful and lacking compassion. The court heard that Hassan was oblivious to the sting and had even bragged to his friends about his relationship with Granger. The trio was caught after Granger's phone records were examined, and police found Hassan's body in a pool of blood in his home. The family of Mehmet Hassan expressed their grief and love for him, stating that his death will haunt them forever.

The passage discusses the recent poor form of Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, particularly during the second half of the season. Fabregas, who captains the Spanish national team, had a strong start to the season but has seen a decline in his performance in recent matches. This has raised concerns about his durability, despite his happiness at Chelsea. The 27-year-old midfielder has struggled to make an impact in recent games, including Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland. His dip in form is evident in his statistics, with only one assist in his last five games, compared to 15 in the first half of the season. This decline has also been noted by his former club Barcelona, who commented on a downward trend in his stats towards the end of each season. Despite this, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping for a resurgence in form from Fabregas, as the team aims to secure the Premier League title with six wins from their remaining nine games.

West Ham is in discussions to sign Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a trial. The 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United spent two weeks training with West Ham's academy and caught the attention of the coaches. Beckford also has offers from clubs in Belgium. In other news, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Premier League. The team is set to move to the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

The passage describes an incident where a huntsman, Mike Lane, was violently assaulted by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars and ropes. The attack occurred during a hunt, despite the hunt being for an artificial scent rather than a fox. The police investigation into the attack has been dropped after three months, despite the victim and other witnesses providing a video of the incident, names of saboteurs, and car registration numbers. The police have been unable to identify or charge any suspects, and the victim has expressed his disappointment with the police's handling of the case. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to make it easier for police to identify and prosecute criminals.

The passage discusses the death of American-born al-Qaeda member, Adam Gadahn, in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a prominent figure in al-Qaeda, serving as its English-language propagandist. He was killed alongside another U.S. citizen and al-Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, in separate operations. The White House also announced the death of Warren Weinstein, a U.S. citizen abducted by al-Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011, in the same operation that killed Farouq. Gadahn, who was 36 at the time of his death, was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al-Qaeda. He was known for his numerous video statements on behalf of the terrorist organization, urging attacks on American, Western, and Jewish interests.

The passage describes the emergence of a young basketball prodigy in China, Mai Zizhuo, who is only five years old. Mai has been practicing basketball since he was two and a half years old. A viral video showcases his impressive skills, including dribbling two basketballs simultaneously and scoring successive hoops. The video has gained him a large following in basketball-loving China. Some netizens express disbelief and question the authenticity of the video, while others compare him to Yao Ming, China's most famous basketball player. Some feel inadequate about their own basketball skills in comparison to Mai.

The passage discusses how Tom O'Carroll, a prominent member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, known for its controversial campaign to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, had previously formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL). Hacked Off, established in response to the phone-hacking scandal, is advocating for state involvement in media regulation, a position that O'Carroll supports. The news of O'Carroll's involvement is likely to be an embarrassment for Hacked Off, given PIE's history and O'Carroll's conviction for "corrupting public morals" in 1981.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday for a unique catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The lifestyle brand, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, produces unisex collections of ten pieces designed to be worn in twenty different ways. The monochrome collection was presented with models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. Guests enjoyed the sunny weather and were treated to nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria. The show took place on a warm 28-degree Celsius day, attracting onlookers from the beach and road above the pool.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a day at a safari park in Northern California with his family, including his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. They interacted with various animals such as giraffes, sea lions, and a rare white tiger. Khan also announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent. He was previously linked with bouts against Adrien Broner, Keith Thurman, and British rival Kell Brook.

The passage describes the removal of a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, from an Israeli memorial at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, which commemorates fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. The removal was due to objections from his family and others, including an organization called Almagor, which represents victims of terror in Israel. The family did not give permission for his name to be included, and Almagor argued that his death was not a result of terrorism. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, decided to remove the teenager's name following complaints. The passage also mentions that three Israelis are being prosecuted for the killing.

The passage describes a video featuring a young boy attempting to use his family's cat as a pillow in the garden. The cat is initially seen grooming itself before the boy lies down on its belly. The cat then moves to a different spot, and the boy follows, repeating the action. This sequence occurs multiple times before the cat eventually leaves. A later video shows the boy and the cat on good terms, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

The passage describes a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, where witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, testified about police wrongdoing. Kushner, 32, was one of the 17 former drug dealers testifying for the federal government. He lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after revealing his past drug dealing history during the trial. Kushner had been arrested in 2007 and the charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. He was also arrested again in 2011 and pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. The six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering have claimed that the government's case is based on the testimonies of 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

6 people were injured in an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, which caused a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill has been reported. The fire is now under control, and the plant had experienced a similar explosion in 2013. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests in several Chinese cities due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low during matches, a superstition he has maintained throughout his life. He uses children's shinpads and has no intention of changing this practice despite some referees advising him to pull his socks up. Grealish made his first Premier League start against QPR on Tuesday, a game that ended in a 3-3 draw. He is pleased to have made his first start but is not entirely happy with the game's outcome. Grealish sees it as just another football match and is grateful for the manager's faith in him, hoping to get a few more starts before the end of the season.

22-year-old Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. She has been in this condition for nearly three months, with a tracheostomy in her throat, and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. Despite this, Bobby Brown's attorney stated that her condition has improved and she will have a long life, but the quality of her life will not be known for years to come as she embarks on a rehabilitation process.

The passage describes the current state of the Fed Cup match between Russia and Germany, with Russia leading 2-0. The first point was won by Svetlana Kuznetsova, who beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. The second point was secured by Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova, who saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki. The match was closely fought, with both players struggling with their serve and Lisicki making a high number of unforced errors. Russia needs one more win to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

The passage discusses the potential for another storm to hit New South Wales later in the week, following severe weather the previous week. Meteorologists predict an east coast low, similar to the one that caused damage and flooding in the Hunter region, could bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that this could hamper clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still needing to be completed. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which was severely impacted by the previous storm. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott stated that the new weather system appears to be moving quickly and may not be as severe as the previous one. The Bureau of Meteorology warned that intense rainfall and strong winds could affect coastal areas in the state's north east, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland.

38-year-old model, Nina Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, was hospitalized after collapsing at home due to low blood pressure, causing heavy bruising on her arms. Italian media initially reported that she attempted suicide, but Moric denied these claims on her Instagram account, stating she is recovering at home. Moric was previously married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

The British public is hoping for a traditional name for Kate and William's second child, with a poll showing that 12% of people favor the name Diana if it's a girl. Alice and Charlotte are the next preferred names, while James and Alexander are favored if it's a boy. Many people are hoping for a girl, with only 3% hoping for a younger brother for George. The majority of Brits also support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

17 people were killed and 64 wounded, including an Afghan lawmaker, when a suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, Afghanistan. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the group was on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility for the attack. No other organization has claimed responsibility. CNN's Masoud Popalzai, Jethro Mullen, and Elizabeth Joseph contributed to this report.

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves, 31, has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that the player had rejected a three-year contract extension, which was dependent on Alves participating in 60% of the club's matches. The negotiations have ended, and Alves will leave the Nou Camp this summer.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently playing for Boca Juniors, has suggested that Italian footballers Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti should consider joining him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has previously played with both Pirlo and Totti, believes that their playing style would be well-suited for Boca Juniors and that the fans would greatly appreciate their talents. Osvaldo's comments were made in an interview with Corriere dello Sport.

The passage describes an incident where amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson fell from his horse during a race at Wincanton, performing a double somersault and landing with only a cut on his nose. The fall has since become an internet sensation, with the video being watched hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson, undeterred by the incident, continues to ride and work at Paul Nicholls's yard, and has gained a few hundred Twitter followers since the incident. He jokes about potentially pursuing a career in gymnastics after racing.

The passage discusses English rugby player James Haskell dressing up as Iron Man and posting the photo on Instagram, coinciding with the release of the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. Haskell, a captain for London Wasps, returned to the club in 2012 after playing for various teams in France, Japan, and New Zealand. He has made over 100 appearances for Wasps and has earned 57 caps for England. The Avengers: Age of Ultron movie premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre, featuring stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson.

The passage discusses the trend of wide leg trousers for Spring/Summer 2015. This style includes denim, cropped, printed, and striped variations. Wide leg trousers are seen as a refreshing alternative to the long-standing skinny jean trend. The key to pulling off this look is to pair the trousers with high heels and a simple top to keep the outfit in proportion. Designers such as Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney have showcased this trend in their collections. High street stores like Topshop and online retailers like Finery London offer more affordable options. Poppy Delevingne has been spotted embracing this trend.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. More than 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie due to its perceived negative depiction of the Middle East and people from that region. However, there was a backlash to this decision, leading to a counter-petition asking school officials to reconsider. The university's vice president for student life stated that it was a mistake to cancel the movie and that the show will go on. The decision was made in order to uphold the university's values of freedom of expression and respect for students' right to make their own choices. As an alternative, a screening of the family-friendly film "Paddington" will be offered for those who would rather not attend "American Sniper." This decision was praised by Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly attempted to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, a small cat-sized animal, survived the incident but was singed. The tourists, aged 18 and 24, were questioned by detectives, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are native to some small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

The passage is about 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at famous New York nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s. She performed with notable artists such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Although films were made of her performances, she had never seen them until Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and a team of volunteers showed her the "soundies" (early music videos) at her nursing home. Barker was thrilled to see herself dancing on screen.

The passage discusses a decline in the practice of washing one's own car in Britain. A study found that one-third of men have never washed their own car, and three-quarters of women also do not wash their own cars. The decline is attributed to various factors such as the rise of hand car washes, the size of modern cars, and the availability of other Sunday activities. The tradition of washing one's own car is less popular in cities like Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh, and more popular in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield. Cars most likely to be washed by their owners are Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least likely to be washed by their owners. The survey was conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV.

The passage primarily discusses Liverpool defender Martin Skrtel's admiration for his teammate and captain, Steven Gerrard, who is set to depart the club at the end of the season. Skrtel highlights Gerrard's significant impact on both him personally and the club as a whole, describing him as one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool. Despite acknowledging the challenge of replacing Gerrard, Skrtel remains optimistic about the club's potential to find suitable replacements with the right support. Both players were suspended for three matches following a defeat to Manchester United in March but are expected to return for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

The passage describes golf legend Jack Nicklaus, at the age of 75, achieving a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first hole-in-one at Augusta. The feat was later matched by Camilo Villegas, who also aced the fourth and eighth holes. The par-3 contest saw a total of five hole-in-ones, tying the record from 2002. Nicklaus, a six-time winner of the Masters, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam. The favorite to win the tournament, Rory McIlroy, has the chance to achieve the career grand slam if he wins the Masters.

The passage describes severe weather conditions in Kansas, with tornadoes reported near Goddard and southwestern Kansas. Nighttime tornadoes are noted to be particularly dangerous. Other states, including Missouri, were also affected by storms, with potential tornado sightings in Potosi and reports of wind damage, flooding, and hail. The severe weather is expected to continue in the Midwest and surrounding areas on Thursday.

The passage discusses the case of Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, who pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting a man, Eric Harris, during an arrest. The judge granted Bates permission to go to the Bahamas for a family vacation, a decision that the Harris family found insensitive. Bates claims the shooting was accidental and that he meant to use his taser instead of his gun. There are allegations that Bates was not qualified to be on the force and received preferential treatment due to his donations to the agency and friendship with the sheriff. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish MMA fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title match against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has recently gotten a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, which he revealed on Instagram with the caption "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor, known as "The Notorious," already has a tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart on his chest. The upcoming bout will be Aldo's eighth defense of his featherweight championship belt, but McGregor has questioned Aldo's motivation, claiming that he himself wants the title more. The two have a tense relationship, and during a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 fans.

The passage describes an incident where Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott drank a beer quickly (skolled) at an Australian rules function, and the subsequent criticism he received from anti-drinking campaigners. The campaigners, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, expressed concern that Abbott's actions glorified binge drinking and reinforced the idea that heavy drinking is associated with masculinity. They argued that this behavior could encourage unhealthy drinking habits and make it harder to promote responsible drinking. The incident also sparked debate among politicians, with some defending Abbott's actions and others suggesting he should set a better example. The passage notes that while drinking is a part of Australian tradition, there is growing concern about binge drinking and its negative consequences.

The state of Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases linked to Scott County, a rise from 106 cases the previous week. The outbreak is primarily among intravenous drug users, specifically involving the use of the painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has since distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with 1,400 used syringes returned. The future of this program and potential legislation to allow needle exchanges in other counties is uncertain, as Pence and some lawmakers have concerns about needle exchanges promoting drug use. The state has typically seen about five HIV cases in Scott County each year.

The passage describes an Arsenal fan who gave his girlfriend, Saskia, a test about his favorite football club. The test, which took the form of a school exam, included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and an "in your own words" section. Saskia scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50, or 87%, and her boyfriend decided not to break up with her as a result. The test included questions about the meaning of "FC" in Arsenal FC, the nickname for Arsenal fans, the current manager of Arsenal, the current home and away kits, the starting 11 squad, and the 2014 FA Cup final. Saskia struggled to name all 11 players of the starting squad and got confused on the player positions. The boyfriend marked the test with red pen and provided feedback, including that Saskia "could have performed better on Q17," needs to "learn all player positions," and should understand that "Tottenham are scum." The passage also includes reactions from Twitter users, with some hailing the boyfriend as a "legend" and others criticizing him for taking things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former undercover informant for the DEA, is facing deportation after working for the agency for 27 years. Toro, once a mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, began working for the DEA after fleeing Colombia and provided information that aided in the prosecution of numerous drug lords, including Carlos Lehder Rivas and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Although he was promised US citizenship for his work, the DEA has not fulfilled this promise, leaving Toro in legal limbo. Despite his contributions, Toro's current temporary visa has expired, and he is at risk of being deported to Colombia, where he fears for his life. DEA Agent Mike McManus, who once worked with Toro, has expressed his support for Toro's efforts to remain in the US.

14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, India, was allegedly gang-raped by five men when she went outside her house to relieve herself. She set herself on fire two days later using kerosene, and is now fighting for her life in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested. The incident has sparked outrage and sensitivity towards sexual assault in India, with recent attacks resulting in street protests and calls for more protection for women. The case has drawn comparisons to the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old student, which led to widespread protests and international outrage.

The passage is about Manchester United's upcoming derby against Manchester City. Manchester United manager, Louis van Gaal, has stated that he is looking forward to the match and hopes to win, which would secure a higher position in the league table. However, he confirmed that key player Robin van Persie will not be playing due to fitness issues. Van Gaal also mentioned that he is excited about experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford for the first time. Another player, Luke Shaw, is also not fit enough to play, according to Van Gaal. The manager emphasized the importance of controlling aggression in the match, referring to their previous loss to Manchester City.

The passage describes a protest by a section of Arsenal and Liverpool fans at the Emirates Stadium against the rising ticket prices in the Barclays Premier League. The protest, which was organized by the Black Scarf Movement, Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, involved fans leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of the match and displaying banners both inside and outside the ground. The fans are expressing their dissatisfaction with the continuing rise of ticket prices, with the cheapest tickets for the lunchtime kick-off costing £64. The protest comes in the wake of the announcement of the Premier League’s £5.14billion TV rights deal, and the fans hope that the image of empty seats will raise awareness of the struggles they face to meet the rising costs of following their clubs. Further protests are expected after the full-time at the Emirates.

The passage describes the story of a newborn baby named Star Reader, who was diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia. After unsuccessful attempts to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant was required for her survival. Neither of her parents were suitable matches, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered to donate part of her liver. The operation was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery. The story highlights the selfless act of the twin sister of Star's mother, who saved her niece's life by donating a part of her liver.

The passage describes a football challenge event sponsored by Audi, in which Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated. The players were divided into two teams and competed in three rounds of challenges, including firing balls into the boot of a car from close range and playing tennis with a high-end Audi R8 V10 Plus as the net. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian won the final round, which involved shooting at cars from long range. A clip at the end of the video shows Willian accidentally breaking the wing mirror of one of the Audi's with a long-range effort.

The passage describes a former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, who caused a highway crash in New Hampshire that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, who was 54 at the time of the sentencing, denied being suicidal during the incident, despite previous claims by prosecutors. The crash occurred in December 2013 when Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph and collided with the couple's SUV. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, and faced 12 to 24 years in prison. The defense argued that Dellinger's actions were influenced by health issues, including Ambien withdrawal, the effects of a psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis. Dellinger, who had held high-level positions at several major companies, had a history of health problems and had argued with his wife about his medications prior to the crash. The victims' families filed a wrongful death lawsuit against Dellinger.

The father of a five-year-old boy, Garnett-Paul Spears, who was killed by his mother, Lacey Spears, through salt poisoning, expressed his anger on Facebook after she was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. The father, Chris Hill, hoped that she would not survive in prison and stated that she deserves to die. The judge who sentenced Spears said she suffers from a mental illness and the crime was still 'unfathomable in its cruelty.' Prosecutors asked for the maximum sentence, stating that Spears made her son ill for attention, while her lawyer requested the minimum 15 years to life, calling her a hardworking single mother who gave her son unconditional love. Spears was found guilty of second-degree murder in the death of her son at a suburban New York hospital.

The influenza vaccine for Australia's upcoming winter has been updated to include protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in flu-related deaths in the Northern Hemisphere due to a poor vaccine match. The new vaccine will be available from April 20, with high-risk groups eligible for free government-funded shots. The vaccine also provides protection against H1N1. The delay in the vaccine's arrival is due to the inclusion of the new strains. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, recommends everyone get the vaccine and book their flu shots now, as it will also be used in the next Northern Hemisphere winter.

The passage discusses the current issues faced by the caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois. The site has received criticism from the National Geographic magazine for its lack of historical character, described as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The tomb's management is under the state's historic preservation agency, which is facing potential budget cuts and restructuring by Governor Bruce Rauner. These changes could impact the management of the historic site. The tomb has undergone renovations and repairs in recent years, with the interior plaster, paint, bronze, and marble construction renovated for approximately $730,000, and waterproofing and landscaping projects currently in progress. Despite the criticism and potential budget cuts, supporters of the site argue that the National Geographic portrayal is unfair.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 90s fashion trends and the potential comeback of JNCO jeans, known for their wide leg openings. It highlights nine fashion trends from the 90s and early 2000s that are considered outdated and should be left in the past. These include bucket hats, camouflage print, excessive denim, Ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. The article features examples of celebrities who wore these trends in the past and those who still wear them today.

The passage is a summary of several trending stories from a particular week. The stories include the appearance of four rainbows in the New York sky, the Chinese government's crackdown on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes, Robert Downey Jr.'s (RDJ) agitated response to a UK interviewer's questions about his private life, a new social media trend inspired by Kylie Jenner's lips, a 102-year-old woman named Alice Barker watching footage of herself dancing in the 1930s and 40s, a controversial prom proposal that was accused of racism, the casting of Ewan McGregor as Lumiere in the upcoming live-action "Beauty and the Beast" film, and a military dad announcing his wife's pregnancy with a "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" reference.

The Miami Open saw Serena Williams achieve her 700th career victory in a match against Sabine Lisicki, who she had previously lost to at Wimbledon 2013. The win secured her a place in the semi-finals, where she was set to face either Sloane Stephens or Simona Halep. The event also marked Andy Murray's 500th win, and both he and Williams were presented with celebratory cakes. Halep reached the semi-finals with a 6-1, 7-5 win over Sloane Stephens.

The passage describes the life and death of Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and owner of the Second Floor cafe in Karachi. The cafe was a hub for free speech, art, and progressive discussions. Mahmud was shot and killed by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on the topic of disappearances in Baluchistan. The killing was a blow to the progressive community in Pakistan, where free speech is often dangerous. Mahmud was known for her bravery and commitment to humanism, love, and tolerance. No one has claimed responsibility for her death, and the motive is still unknown.

The passage describes the situation of 82-year-old Mangu Ram, a Hindu refugee who fled to Indian Kashmir during the partition of India and has been denied citizenship rights for the past 70 years. Despite living in India's only Muslim-majority state, he and other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) are unable to own property or vote in state elections, leading to a life of poverty and marginalization. With the recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in a state vote, there is hope for change. The WPRs, who number around 100,000 and mostly live in the Jammu region, have been denied residential rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the state. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has pledged to normalize the status of the WPRs, and with their entry into a governing coalition in Kashmir, there is hope for progress. However, the community is prepared to take matters into their own hands if their hopes are not realized.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a transfer to Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer for the player. Muto, aged 22, is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his skills. Chelsea are looking to loan Muto to their partner club Vitesse Arnhem for the next season. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes that the player has the potential to be a success at Chelsea due to his intelligence, speed, and strength. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has admitted to knowing a little about Muto, but declined to comment further due to the player being under contract with FC Tokyo. Chelsea's transfer policy is influenced by commercial interests, including a recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre manufacturer Yokohama Rubber.

The passage discusses the recent decision by Australia to drop their policy of not selecting their best players if they are based overseas, and argues that England should follow suit. The author highlights the examples of Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who are playing well for Toulon, and Steffon Armitage, who has improved since moving to France. The author also mentions Jonny Wilkinson, who became a better player after moving to France. The author argues that England should be able to select their best team, regardless of where they play, and that this will give them the best chance of winning the World Cup. The author also notes that other countries, such as South Africa and Wales, select players who are based overseas.

The passage describes Open Garden's development of a device called Greenstone, which is designed to strengthen off-the-grid networks. Open Garden had previously created the Firechat app, which allows users to chat without the need for internet or mobile signal by utilizing wireless mesh networks. Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move more easily within these networks. The device takes advantage of Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) in iOS 7, which creates a wireless mesh network connecting phones to each other. Messages are sent securely and can be sent anonymously. Greenstone is still under development and currently works with Firechat at a range of around 20 feet. It can hold up to 1,000 of the most recent messages and has a one-year battery life. Open Garden is working with manufacturers to design and sell Greenstone.

The passage describes a burlesque performer, Lillian Bustle, who is working to change the negative perception surrounding the word 'fat' by using it as a positive, body-positive descriptor for her own physique. She argues that 'fat' should not be synonymous with 'ugly'. Lillian's views are not universally accepted, as size discrimination in the workplace has increased by 66% in the past 30 years. However, she believes that exposure to diverse body types can lead to greater acceptance. Lillian, who weighs 240lbs, uses burlesque as a platform to challenge societal norms and promote body positivity. Her TED talk, which was posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has received positive feedback and has inspired many to reconsider their perceptions of different body types.

Theo Walcott, along with six other Arsenal teammates, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. The group, including runway model Olga Sherer, posed for an official portrait. Walcott has been frequently seen on the bench this season, being named as a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games. He made a brief appearance in Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea and is hoping to start in Arsenal's upcoming match against Hull.

The passage describes an upcoming auction of props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker's collection, which includes items from films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. The auction, taking place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at Propstore.com on May 29, features 417 original items from more than 50 productions, with an estimated value of $746,100. Some of the highlighted items include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, valued at $40,000, the Two-Face mask from Batman Forever, listed at $1,500, and the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas, estimated at $8,000. The collection also includes items from other films Baker worked on, such as An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker.

The passage describes the tragic death of 7-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, while on a ski holiday in the French Alps. Carwyn, a competent skier and snowboarder, became separated from his family during their last run of the day. He ventured into dense woodland and fell over a 164ft drop. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. The family, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, described Carwyn as a "daring, outgoing and determined" youngster who "made life full of laughter with never a dull moment". They expressed their devastation and the void left in their hearts by his death. The family had been enjoying their ski holiday together prior to the accident.

15-year-old Laura Scurr, from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with having the perfect figure. She survived on just one piece of fruit a day, leading to a collapse due to starvation. She was hospitalized and put on a heart monitor for a week. Laura's obsession with weight loss began due to bullying and societal pressures to be thin. She received support from eating disorder organizations and has since made a recovery. She has spoken out about the pressures on young girls to be a size zero and is now a semi-finalist in Miss Teen GB, a contest that promotes positive body image.

The passage describes the launch of Liverpool's new home kit for the 2015/2016 season, designed by New Balance. Players such as Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet were present at Anfield to unveil the kit. Despite Sterling's recent controversial interview where he rejected a new contract offer from Liverpool, the club insists he will not be leaving this summer. Fans at the event expressed their desire for Sterling to stay, with one fan urging him to ensure he is seen in the new kit next season. The kit features all-white branding and a new style of collar. Liverpool legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush were also present at the launch.

The largest high-definition map of dark matter has been created by the University of Manchester, covering 0.4% of the sky. The map is part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES) and was made using data from the Dark Energy Camera, which captures the shapes of galaxies to infer the amount of dark matter in a given area. Dark matter is an invisible substance that makes up at least 80% of the matter in the universe and can only be observed through its gravitational effects on visible matter. The DES aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy. The survey's analysis supports the theory that galaxies form where there are large concentrations of dark matter, as shown by the map's large filaments of matter and cosmic voids. The team at Manchester analyzed 130 million telescope images of galaxies to create the map, a process that requires extremely precise measurements and powerful supercomputers.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old winger, Memphis Depay. PSV's technical director has confirmed the contact, stating that United are keen to make Depay one of their first signings this summer. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, has previously worked with United manager Louis van Gaal during Holland's successful 2014 World Cup campaign. The Dutch giants have confirmed interest from other big European clubs, including Paris-Saint Germain, but United appear to be in pole position to sign the Dutch star. Depay, who started his career at VV Moordrecht before moving to PSV at the age of 12, is known for his pace, dribbling skills, and powerful right foot.

The passage describes a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City's youth teams. Chelsea won the match 3-1, with two goals from Tammy Abraham and one from Dominic Solanke. The match was part of the Youth Cup Final and took place at Manchester City's Academy Stadium. The Chelsea team featured a strong defense and a potent attack, with Abraham and Solanke causing particular problems for the City defense. The City team, while competitive, struggled to contain Chelsea's forwards and were ultimately unable to overcome the deficit. The match was a commanding performance from Chelsea, who took a significant lead back to West London.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that he believes people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between a man and a woman. He thinks states should decide on gay marriage through political debate and legislature, not courts. He also mentioned that he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cares for, despite not agreeing with the decision.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia respectively, are on a cycling journey around the world with no set agenda or cause, aiming to discover different parts of the planet at their own pace. They have covered approximately 7,000 miles through 16 countries in 356 days, living on less than 3 euros each per day. They primarily camp outdoors or use hosting websites for accommodation and spend most of their budget on food. They started in London, traveled through Europe, and recently entered Asia, crossing through Turkey and Georgia, with plans to continue into the Pacific and the American continent. They intend to be on the road for several years.

The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly providing a photo booth that printed racist slurs on the pictures from their 2012 wedding. The couple was not informed of the incident until months after the celebration. When the groom contacted Evans, he reportedly did not apologize and told the couple to "sue" him. The couple is suing the company under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied all allegations. The case is set for trial in July if mediation scheduled for tomorrow does not result in an agreement. The couple seeks an apology from Evans.

Mike Brown, England full-back, has admitted to taking a cautious approach in recovering from a recent concussion. He had to withdraw from a Harlequins match against Saracens at Wembley due to this issue. Brown is being cautious to avoid extended breaks or long-term effects, unlike other players such as Johnny Sexton and George North who have also suffered from concussions. Brown's concussion occurred during England's match against Italy in February, and he has since been undergoing World Rugby online modules to learn about the symptoms and dangers of concussions. He is currently following a gradual return-to-play protocol, which includes a 20-minute bike ride, to ensure his safe return to the sport.

The frequency of sexual activity among British couples has decreased since the emergence of the internet, with a typical couple now having sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. This decline may be attributed to the increasing integration of public and private lives, as people are constantly checking their emails and have less "quiet empty time." The theory is that as technology has improved, our lives have become busier, eroding the boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, and squeezing out time spent with romantic partners. Researcher Catherine Mercer suggests that dealing with work emails late in the evening can make it difficult to focus solely on one's partner at bedtime.

The Tibetan Mastiff, a breed of dog known for its loyalty and ability to herd other animals, was once a highly sought-after status symbol in China, with some puppies selling for up to £1.2 million. However, the breed's popularity has since plummeted, with many of the dogs being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat used for cheap hotpots. The decline in popularity is attributed to China's anti-corruption crackdown, as the dogs were often given as gifts to officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities. A recent rescue of 20 Tibetan Mastiffs, who were being transported to a slaughterhouse, highlights the cruel fate that many of these dogs are facing. The breed's decline in popularity is also due to unscrupulous breeding practices, which have led to a glut of poor-quality dogs that cannot be sold.

The passage discusses a survey of 600 women in Paris, which found that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on the city's public transport. Half of the women reported being assaulted before the age of 18. The harassment ranges from verbal abuse to sexual assault and rape. The survey results led to calls for a campaign to address this issue, as it significantly impacts women's freedom and safety. The report highlights that women often modify their behavior to avoid harassment, and that the problem is often underreported. The High Council for Gender Equality is advocating for better education and awareness about this issue.

The passage describes a competition called #everydayfix, organized by a company called Direct Line. The competition aims to find solutions for common everyday problems, such as forgetting to lock the door or running out of phone battery. Three prototypes were shortlisted from a design makeathon: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for a good night's sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that indicates whether the door is locked or not; and Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger. The winning prototype will be chosen through a Twitter poll and will be developed into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign.

The police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public money to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, of which she is a director. The chief constable of Northumbria, Sue Sim, also sits on the charity's top table. The funding was secured after the Home Secretary allowed PCCs to commission services for victims of crime. Critics, including Keith Vaz, the Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, have described the selection of the charity as inappropriate and a conflict of interest. Vera Baird has defended her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures and protocols were adhered to. The Ministry of Justice has confirmed it will investigate the circumstances to conclude whether any conflict of interest rules have been broken. The charity was established after the number of people contacting its predecessor, Victim Support, plummeted.

Four individuals were involved in the brutal assault and torture of a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, in Philadelphia. The incident occurred in late March 2014 in the basement of a house in Mayfair, where Valecce was staying. The group, led by Corry 'Corey' Campbell, believed Valecce had hurt Campbell's cat and stolen money and drugs. Over the course of 42 hours, Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive images and phrases by Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and their friend Carl Halin. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was able to escape and contact the police on April 1. All three were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment. Campbell and Halin were sentenced to 20 years in state prison, while Ng received a sentence of 23 months. Two other individuals, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's Dutch international winger, Memphis Depay. The 21-year-old has been in prolific form this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. Depay, who was part of Holland's 2014 World Cup squad under current United manager Louis van Gaal, is also being pursued by other top European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain. PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, has confirmed the interest from United and other clubs, with Depay's value having significantly increased since a £15 million offer from Tottenham was rebuffed last summer. Depay, who started his career at Dutch amateur side VV Moordrecht before joining PSV at the age of 12, is known for his pace, dribbling skills, and powerful right foot.

The 2009 convention had over 512 attendees, including notable guests Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell, as well as musical performers.
